Delicia tiene 49 años, es muy alegre y servicial con las personas; sobre todo con los niños, ya que tiene 4 hijos, siendo cada uno de ellos sus más grandes tesoros con los que vive en la casa que heredó de sus padres.

Ella se dedica a la prestar sus servicios como ama de casa en varias viviendas de su localidad, donde es muy querida. Eta actividad la viene realizando desde hace 4 años, desde que su pareja tuvo que viajar fuera de la ciudad en busca de mejoras económicas, por lo tanto tuvo que buscar la manera de cubrir los gastos diarios en casa. Gracias a la recomendación de algunas amigas empezó a trabajar limpiando casas y cuidando ancianos y niños; encontrando en ello, su verdadera vocación.
Ahora Delicia considera que prestar sus servicios tiene un nuevo significado y lo que más anhela es abrir un centro de rehabilitación, donde se vele por el bienestar de las personas más indefensas.

Este es su noveno crédito en microfinanzas PRISMA y está segura de seguir conformando un bonito equipo de trabajo con su banco comunal, donde cada uno de los miembros se tiende la mano. Con el dinero que ahora solicita planes adquirir algunos materiales necesarios para seguir prestando sus servicios.
texts.en:
Delicia is 49 years old. She is very happy and friendly with people; especially with children, as she has 4 of her own, who are her greatest treasures. She lives with them in a house she inherited from her parents. Delicia provides housekeeping services in various homes in her neighborhood, where she is well loved. She has done this type of work for 4 years, ever since her spouse had to leave the city to search for a better economic situation. She therefore had to find a way to cover the daily expenses at home. Thanks to recommendations from friends, she began work cleaning houses and caring for the elderly and children: and found it to be her true calling. Now Delicia feels that being of service has a new meaning, and what she wants most is to open a rehabilitation center, where she can provide for the wellbeing of those who are most defenseless. This is her ninth loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA and she is sure she will continue to be a part of a good working team at her communal bank, where each of the members support each other. With the money she is currently requesting, she plans to purchase materials she needs to continue providing her services.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products for work

loans.name: Naidan

texts.en:
Naidan G. manages a wood crafts business with the help of her husband, Davaanyam. They produce a variety of traditional Mongolian wood crafts including plates and horse-head fiddles. G. and her husband work well together – he designs and crafts the products and she decorates and paints them. The couple started their wood crafts business in 2006 after selling consumer goods for the previous 11 years. They have quickly grown a stable operation and attribute their success to the high quality of their products. Their earnings have enabled them to build a new home for their family.

G. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Uvs province in western Mongolia. Her young son and daughter are both in kindergarten. G. and her husband are open-minded and hardworking people and are well respected in their community. They are very proud of their business and feel that it is important to produce these traditional crafts so that future generations stay in touch with Mongolia's history. They are requesting a 1,800,000 tugrug loan to purchase wood and supplies for their wood crafts business.

loans.use: To purchase wood and supplies for their wood crafts business

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
Felipa es una mujer apasionada con su trabajo, a pesar de tener 57 años se levanta todos los días con ánimos para seguir laborando. Ella  vive con su hija Vanesa, de 20 años, y con su hermana Margarita, en una modesta y bien cuidada casa ubicada al sur de la ciudad de Lima.

Todos los días se dedica al cuidado y peinado de los cabellos de sus clientes, pues es peluquera de profesión y se dedica a este oficio casi toda su vida, más o menos calcula que son 30 años desde que empezó.
A Felipa le agrada mucho dedicarse a su salón de belleza, porque no solo le genera buenos  ingresos económicos, si no también porque con este trabajo ha sacado adelante a su hija y está muy orgullosa de haberlo logrado. Un buen día se le ocurrió instalar un salón y hacerlo sola, como hasta ahora, además se sabe abastecer con los únicos instrumentos que jamás le fallarán, sus manos. A pesar de ser un trabajo muy agotador Felipa piensa algún día tener un salón de belleza más amplio, con mejores herramientas y comodidad para sus clientes, quienes día a día aumentan, ya que las manos de ella son casi mágicas y peinan de una manera prodigiosa. 

Este es el cuarto préstamo que tiene con MFP y se compromete, una vez más, a ser exacta con cada uno de sus pagos. Piensa invertir el dinero que solicita en la compra de herramientas más modernas para su salón de belleza, además de mejorar sus instalaciones, pues no descansará hasta que su local sea el mejor de la zona.
texts.en:
Felipa is a woman who is passionate about her work. Despite being 57 years old, she gets up every day excited to keep working. She lives with her 20-year-old daughter Vanesa and her sister Margarita in a modest and well cared for house in the southern part of the city of Lima. Every day, she styles her customers' hair. She is a hairdresser by profession and she has been doing this kind of work almost her whole life. She estimates that it was about 30 years ago that she started. Felipa really enjoys her work because not only does it generate a good income but it has allowed her to give her daughter a good start in life and she is very proud of having been able to do that. One day, it just occurred to her to start up a salon on her own and that's how it has continued until now. She knows to rely on the only tools that will never fail her, her hands. Although her work is very tiring, Felipa would like to someday have a larger salon with better equipment and a more comfortable setting for her client base, which continues to grow daily since her hands are almost magic and she styles hair in a phenomenal way. This is her fourth loan with MFP and she is once again committed to be timely with her repayments. She plans to invest the money from the loan in the purchase of more modern equipment for her beauty salon and in improvements to the salon itself. She will not rest until her salon is the best in the area.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of new equipment

loans.name: Sanyazbek

texts.en:
Sanyazbek H. operates a grocery in his town. He started in the grocery business in 1999, selling goods in partnership with his older brother. The two built a stable operation and made much progress with their business. However, in 2006, H. used his earnings to start his own grocery. With his past experience and knowledge of the trade, he was quickly able to establish a good position in the local business community. H. purchases and transports his products from both Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, and China. He is always focused on the future and dreams of one day opening a grocery trading center. H. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugriks loan to import grocery products from China.

H. is 36 years old and lives with his parents, wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Both his daughter and son, ages 14 and 9, attend a local secondary school.

loans.use: To import grocery products from China

loans.name: Florentina

texts.es:
Florentina es una comerciante de 50 años, vive con su esposo (Jesús), que tiene 51 años. Ellos viven felices en su acogedora casa ubicada en un populoso distrito al sur de la ciudad de Lima.

Desde hace 10 años se dedica a la atención de su tienda de productos comestibles, ella notó la necesidad de este tipo de negocio en su zona, y fue así como se animó a emprender su propia bodega, pues no había competencia y además podía hacerlo desde la comodidad de su hogar.
A Florentina, más conocida como Flor, le gusta su negocio porque puede darse el lujo de ser su propia jefa y también administrarlo sin problema; además le es muy rentable, ya que es una buena opción en la zona porque no sólo ofrece productos comestibles como en cualquier bodega, sino también vende carne de pollo fresca y sus clientes prefieren ir a su tienda que caminar hasta el mercado.
Para el futuro, como buena empresaria piensa en hacer crecer su negocio y quizás contratar a alguien para que la ayude, ya que a veces no logra abastecerse sola.


Este es el segundo préstamo que tiene con MFP y está segura, como en la primera ocasión, que será muy puntual en sus pagos, pues sabe que en los negocios el tiempo es muy importante. También le gusta el trabajo de su banco comunal porque es muy gratificante compartirlo con personas responsables. Con el dinero que ahora solicita surtirá mejor su tienda, con mayor cantidad de productos para ofrecerles a sus clientes calidad y garantía.
texts.en:
Florentina is a 50-year old shopkeeper who lives with her husband Jesús who is 51 years old. They live happily in their cozy house which is located in highly populated area in southern Lima. For the last 10 years, she has sold groceries. She noted the need for this type of product in her area and that was how she got started with her own store since there was no competition and she could do it from the comfort of her own home. Florentina, who is usually known as Flor, likes her business because she has the luxury of being her own boss and can run things smoothly. Also, her business is very profitable since it is a good option in the area as it offers more than other corner stores such as fresh chicken. Her customers prefer to come to her store rather than walk to the market. For the future, as a good businesswoman, she would like to grow her business and perhaps contract someone to help her since sometimes she can't keep up with demand on her own. This is her second loan with MFP and she's sure that she will be very punctual with her repayments as she was with those for the first loan since she knows that timing is very important in business. She likes working with her village bank because it is very rewarding to work with such responsible people. With the money that she's requesting, she will buy supplies for her store to be able to offer her customers a wider variety of quality products.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
This is Cecilia N., 37 years old. She lives with her family in a Habitat for Humanity village in Baseco Compound, Port Area, Manila. For ten years now, Cecilia has been selling used clothing. Then, three months ago, she ventured into direct selling of cosmetics. Her husband is an electrician. Three of their five children are in grade school.

Cecilia joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She has finished repaying her previous loan with CCT and is expecting a new loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos as fresh capital for her business. She is currently earning 14,000 Philippine pesos a month. From her profits, she has been able to renovate their government-subsidized row-house unit. She dreams of owning a delivery vehicle that she can use to transport her used clothing.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response to poverty and social injustice. It is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and an evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. CCT serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Horencia

texts.es:
Horencia es una atenta mujer de 56 años, vive con sus 3 hijos: Fátima de 19, Esteban de 16 y Ricardo de 14 años. Ella se esfuerza cada día para entregar lo mejor de sí, no solo a su familia, sino también a sus clientes.

Pues desde hace 8 años esta simpática dama tiene un negocio de imprenta en su casa, ofrece los servicios de impresión de diferentes tipos de boletas, facturas y todo lo que se refiere al rubro a bajos precios. El negocio lo atiende con sus hijos, quienes la ayudan cuando terminan sus quehaceres estudiantiles. Horencia no se detiene y quiere lograr ampliar su negocio, ofrecer un mejor servicio y adquirir modernos implementos para su imprenta, pues como ella dice “es más cómodo mandar a imprimir por acá que por el centro, y el servicio es igual”; además sabe que algún día este negocio será la mejor herencia para sus hijos. 
Los días tranquilos de esta apacible mujer transcurren entre pedidos, conversaciones con los clientes, y un aroma a papel, sabe que su imprenta será más grande y casi lo puede imaginar, sólo necesita dar lo mejor de sí para lograrlo.

Ella ya tiene tiempo trabajando con MFP, este es su noveno préstamo, el cual una vez más lo invertirá para bien en la mejora de su negocio. Pero también piensa invertir en la compra de golosinas para la venta, pues el servicio de imprenta no es muy activo, y ella siempre piensa como negociante.
texts.en:
Horencia is a very polite woman of 56 who lives with her 3 children: Fátima, age 19; Esteban, age 16; and Ricardo, age 14. She works hard every day to give the best of herself, not only to her family, but also to her customers. For the past eight years, this amiable lady has operated a printing business in her home, offering printing services for various types of tickets, receipts, and all other related items at low prices. She operates the business with her children, who help her when they finish their schoolwork. Horencia is not stopping here, however; she wants to expand her business, offering better service and acquiring modern equipment for her print shop, since, as she says, "it is more convenient to have something printed here than downtown, and the service is the same." She also knows that someday her business will be the best legacy she can leave her children. The tranquil days of this serene woman are filled with printing orders, conversations with customers, and the smell of paper. She knows that her print shop will someday be bigger, and she can almost visualize it; she only needs to give the best of herself in order to achieve it. Horencia has already worked with MFP for some time; this is her ninth loan, which once again will be put to good use as an investment in improving her business. However, she is also thinking about investing in the purchase of some snacks to sell in her shop, since the printing business is not constantly active, and she is always thinking like an entrepreneur.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investing in expanding her business

loans.name: Baba Jan

texts.en:
Baba jan is the son of S. N.. He lives in district 16th of Kabul Afghanistan. He is about 38 years old and married with four children. He has two daughters and two sons and all of them are school students. 

Baba jan has a general store where he sells different kinds of materials. He would like to take an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani to purchase things that are not available in his shop. He hopes that with this loan he will progress a lot and will attract lots of clients to his shop.

He is grateful to all the Kiva lenders for supporting the entrepreneurs around the world and making them start and sustain new businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more items for his shop

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María es una mujer de  40 años, dentro de su localidad es reconocida por el empeño con el que  realiza su  trabajo, con el fin de brindar a sus hijos las comodidades necesarias para su desarrollo.

La venta de verduras es la actividad que realiza desde hace 8 años en el puesto que adquirió en el mercado de su distrito. Aquí vende trabajo junto a su hermana, con quien comparte el negocio, tratando de apoyarse una a la otra. 
Lo que más le agrada a María es atender a sus clientas, pues cada día con alguna de ellas mantiene conversaciones muy amenas, logrando que su trabajo sea menos fatigado.
Por otro lado, María considera que la rentabilidad de su negocio está en mantener surtido su puesto con diversos productos que llamen la atención de las personas, y que sobre todo, sean de buena calidad. 
Sus planes a futuro son de ampliar su negocio, instalando un nuevo puesto dentro del mercado para así vender otro rubro de productos comestibles.

Este es su noveno crédito con microfinanzas PRISMA y sabe que el tiempo que permanezca será gracias a su grado de responsabilidad y puntualidad con los pagos dentro del banco comunal del cual forma parte. Con el dinero que solicita invertirá en la compra de mayor cantidad de mercadería para incrementar sus ventas.
texts.en:
María is a 40-year-old woman who is recognized in her community for the dedication and effort she brings to her work. Her aim in this is to provide her children with the support they need for their development. For the past 8 years, she has operated a business selling vegetables, from a stand she acquired in her district's marketplace. She sells her products there, working together with her sister, with whom she shares the business, each making an effort to support the other. What María enjoys most is serving her customers, since every day she has very pleasant conversations with some of them, making her work less tiring. At the same time, María believes that the profitability of her business depends on keeping her stand stocked with a diversity of products that attract customers' attention, and above all, products of excellent quality. Her plans for the future are to expand her business, adding a new stand within the market so that she can sell another category of food products. This is María's ninth loan with PRISMA Microfinances, and she knows that her future with the organization will depend on her level of responsibility and the punctuality of her payments within the communal bank she belongs to. The funds she is requesting will be invested in buying a larger quantity of merchandise to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding her inventory of merchandise

loans.name: Baasanjav

texts.en: Baasanjav O. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and 17-year-old son in Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. Her son currently attends a secondary school in the city and her husband, Byambahuu, works as a plumber. O. used to work as a storekeeper for most of her life, but retired several years ago. Today, her income comes from renting out a room in her house to university students. Ulaanbaatar has a large student population as many students from around the country attend the many universities in the city. The rent money has allowed O. to pay her son's tuition fees, and she is making plans to increase her earnings. She says, "I would like to build an addition to my house so that I have more space to rent to students." She is requesting a 1,380 USD loan in order to refurbish her home's heating stove.

loans.use: To refurbish her home's heating stove

loans.name: Tsagaan

texts.en: Tsagaan Narantsetseg is 55 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She currently operates a grocery trading business out of a shipping container at a local market. To supplement her earnings, she also has a billiards table in front of the container so customers can stop and play while they shop. Narantsetseg started her business in 1995 with her capital of 300,000 tugrugs. She has gained much selling experience and knowledge of her trade over the years, and attributes her success to her good accounting skills. Today, her working capital exceeds 700,000 tugrugs. In the future, she hopes to grow her business and move out of her shipping container, which is a very uncomfortable workplace. She says, "I hope to own a stall in the trading center where I can work comfortably." She also plans to use her future earnings to remodel her house. Narantsetseg is requesting a 550,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell

loans.name: Gombosuren

texts.en: P. is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. Both of her children attend the university and her husband helps her with the family business. P. operates a dairy retail business at the local market. She began the business in 2006 with working capital of 800,000 tugrugs. Since then, her business has become very successful and her working capital now exceeds 3,500,000 tugrugs. Because her business has become so successful, her family has been able to build their own home, purchase a car, and are in the process of building a home for her oldest child. P. is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more milk and dairy products in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more milk and dairy products

loans.name: Abrahim Khil Group

texts.en:
This is the Abrahim Khil group. This group is made up of three members. Abdul Mahroof, who is in the middle of the photo, is the group leader. He is a man who is 60 years old. He is married and has seven children, four sons and three daughters. He runs a general store where his oldest son, who is 30, helps him as well. 
These three members have requested a group loan of 30,000 Afghani. G. Nabi, who is the second member of Abrahim Khil group, sells mobile cards. This business supports his family members and his purpose of getting a loan is to expand his business. The last member is Najeeba, who is a tailor. Since the Taliban regime, she has sewn clothes because at that time they had lots of economic problems. Now with the Kiva loan she wants to buy a new sewing machine and start her business in a new way to support her husband and children.
They all would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Tsedevsuren

texts.en: Tsedevsuren B. is 24 years old and lives with his wife and 3-year-old child in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His wife works as a food technician for a private company. B. operates a transport service in his town. He uses a large van, or microbus, to transport people between his province and Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. B. started his transportation business in 2004 after purchasing his microbus.  He has found success with his business and has gained much experience as a driver over the years. His working capital has increased from 800,000 tugrugs when he started to a level exceeding 2,500,000 today. B. is a very honest and hardworking person and is known by his customers for his good character. In the future, he hopes to continue to provide a quality and efficient transportation service, but his dream is to open a small bakery shop in his town. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase new parts for his microbus.

loans.use: To purchase new parts for his microbus

loans.name: Clinic Group

texts.en:
This is Clinic Group. This group has three members, Ajmal, Razia and Rakia. who all live in district 8 of Kabul Afghanistan.

Ajmal is the group leader. He is 25 and single. He lives in a family of six members. He has a shop where he sells vegetables. He is a hard-working man and supports his family through his shop’s income.

Razia, the second member of this group, has a shared business with her husband. She cleans fruits and packages them, and her husband sells them in his cart in the market. This is the only business through which they support a family of 6 members.

Rakia’s brother has a business selling mobile cards. He works in order to pay for all the expenses of his family.

They have requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani to expand their businesses and complete the requirements. They would like to say "lots of thanks!" to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his vegetable business

loans.name: Aireen

texts.en:
Aireen M. is 31 years old and happily married to 41-year-old Ariel M. who is a security guard. They have two children. Darlyn Joyce is 10 years old and Precious Zyrene is 2 years old. Only their eldest child is in school. That is why Aireen and her husband Ariel take it as an opportunity to save more for their family until her second child starts school. One source of income is her husband's salary from his work. Although her husband tries hard to earn enough income for them, it is never enough. So to augment her husband's salary, Aireen thinks of a business that will also contribute income for their expenses and allow them to be able to save.

When she joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she wisely used every loan that she received. She always used it to improve her variety store, like today when she will use her loan to buy assorted groceries to sell in her store. She is hoping that her business will always do well.

One dream of Aireen's is that her children finish college. They would do everything just to make this dream possible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her variety store business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine E. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 41 years old. Josephine is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over five years with approximate average monthly earnings of 1,700 PHP for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita has been married to her husband Jonie for almost 20 years now. She has two kids with him. The eldest is 19 years old. She is a rice farmer and does her very best to keep her crops healthy and growing. She thanks God for bringing CEVI into her town and sees it as an answered prayer. 

She is now requesting a loan of PHP 12,000, which she will use to buy fertilizer and other inputs her farm needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Chiehon

texts.ru: Чиехон Рахматуллоев проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 34 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена-домохозяйка. Чиехон имеет собственный магазин в котором более 12 лет занимается торговлей. Он в основном торгует продуктами питания. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Chiehon R. lives in the city of Kulob. He is 34 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. Chiehon owns a store, where he has been involved in retail sales for over 12 years. He primarily sells food products. He is requesting a loan in order to increase product turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing product turnover

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: Francisca is a 53-year-old married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has six children. The eldest is 25 years old. Aside from rice farming, she also plants corn. Despite having a good harvest from her rice crops, she still needs additional capital for her corn. A member of CEVI for more than a year now, she requested a loan of PHP 12,000. She will use this loan to purchase corn seeds and other farm inputs she needs to grow her farm.

loans.use: To purchase corn seed and other farm inputs

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en: Sylvia is a 47-year-old single mother of five children between the ages of 15 and 20 years.  All her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-room house where she is staying with four people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water.  She owns a hardware shop in Natete Kigaga Zone and pays for transport costs to and from shopping.  On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business eight months and with MCDT six years, servicing her 17th loan, working with the same groupmates. Her monthly expenses include school fees and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and thieves. Sylvia wants to use this loan to buy more bags of cement, iron sheets and nails. She aspires to see her business grow stronger and start buying directly from producers.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cement, nails and iron sheets

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda F. is 34 years old and happily married to her partner in life, Edgar F., 37 years old. They have four children who are equally divided in gender, 2 boys and 2 girls. Danica is now 11 years old, Laline 8 years old, Darius 5 years old and Dennis 4 years old. All of them are now studying in the first level of education, so there are more expenses for their tuition fees plus the daily expenses in the house. The main source of their income is from their buy and sell fruit and peanut business. Her husband is her partner in improving their business. Through their perseverance and with enough capital for the business, they are sure they can make their business grow.

Through the help of the loans that she received from Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), her business has continue to run for 10 years now because she always properly utilized the loans that she received. For this fifth time of taking a loan, she will buy things that are needed for her business. And she is sure that it will last for many years because they will to everything to make it grow.

One dream of Glenda's is to make her business grow big enough so they can have a store place in their market. So she will double her work with the help of her husband so that this dream will be possible. And of course, the result of this is enough income for them and enough money to send her children through college.

loans.use: To finance her buy and sell of fruits business

loans.name: Mae

texts.en: At the early age of 20, Mae got married to her husband Elmo Frank. Now at 29, she has three children; the eldest is 9 years old. Mae tends a rice field. Since the rice field is her source of income, she makes sure her rice crops are healthy. She aims to have a quality harvest. To help her achieve that, she applied for a loan of PHP 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other inputs her farm needs. Mae will also be using part of the loan to pay the laborers who help at her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer and pay the farm laborers

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is a 58 year widow, with eight children, aged between 24 and 38 years.  None of her children goes to school. She resides and owns a two room house where she is staying with five people .The family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Victoria takes care of additional family members.  She owns a piggery farm at her home in Ndeeba Kigaga Zone and pays for transport costs to and from shopping for feed.  On average she receives about  3 customers a day. She works in the out skirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for six years. She is servicing  her 7th loan. Her main business challanges include defaulters and thieves. Victoria  wants to use this loan to buy more bags of  feeds and piglets She aspires to see her business grow stronger and hopes to start buying feed directly from producers.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and piglets

loans.name: Johanna

texts.en: Johanna tries her very best to ensure her farm is in a good condition. She is a 34-year-old farmer who resides in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to avail of its financial service, which she really needs. She is now requesting a loan of Php12, 000. She will use this loan to purchase seed and fertilizer and also to pay the laborers who help at her farm. Johanna would be very grateful for this loan as it would greatly assist her family.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Joserecto

texts.en:
Joserecto believes that success in business can be achieved if a person handles it very well. He is a 49-year-old married farmer with five children to love and take care of. One of his goals in life is to send all his children to school to give them proper education. He is very serious when it comes to his farm because it provides his family with food on the table, clothes to wear and also supports his children’s education. 

He requested a loan from CEVI amounting to Php12, 000. This loan will be used to purchase farm inputs needed at his farm and hopefully help Joserecto achieve his goals in life.

loans.use: Farm Financing

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
At the age of 49, Isabel C. is living without a partner because her husband has already passed away. Although their children are still there, they are now busy improving their own lives with their families. Isabel doesn’t mind that because she also wants to help their three children, Charlote, Rodante and Ronnel, to improve their lives. Because only one of Isabel's children got the opportunity to receive a two-year college degree, she is working really hard to help her grandchildren pursue good educations.

Since joining Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), Isabel has always used the loans she received to improve her businesses, which consist of pig-raising, rice sales, and the operation of a variety store. All of her businesses help to meet their daily expenses, but she is requesting a new loan to buy additional goods for her variety store as well as rice for resale. Isabel's hope is that her businesses will continue to grow, thus enabling her to save for the future of her grandchildren.

loans.use: To finance her variety store and also her rice vending business

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia C., from the village of Owaon, is 45 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Cynthia plants and harvests a variety of vegetables for sale. Engaged in her business for over six years, she earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Cynthia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, she is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers. This loan will be her fifth from PMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Belen

texts.en:
Belen S., a 44-year-old store owner who lives in Maricaban, Pasay City, is wed to Nelson, a company driver. Two of their four children are currently enrolled in college. Three years ago, Belen opened a school and office supplies store in front of their house, a business from which she earns P6,000.00 a month. Her profits are helpful in improving their standard of living.

Belen became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007. She has just finished repaying her previous loans from the cooperative and has applied for a new loan in the amount of P15,000.00 as additional capital for her school and office supplies store. She hopes to soon transfer her store to a place near the school in order to boost revenue.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy school supplies for her business

loans.name: Bibi Bekam Group

texts.en:
Bibi Bekam is the group leader of the Bibi Bekam group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their own businesses.

Bibi Bekam and Shazya want a loan for their tailoring business. They will use the loan to buy necessary materials for their business. Zabeer wants a loan for his embroidery business. And Abobakar wants a loan for his general store. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to earn more money to support their families and solve their problems. They believe that these loans can be very useful because they provide a chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy materials for a tailoring business

loans.name: Habeba Group

texts.en:
This is Habeba group. This group has three members, Habeba, Arezo and Havzen. They all live in Kabul, Afghanistan.

Habeba is the group leader. She is 40 years old and lives in a family of five members. She wants to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving. She is a hard-working woman who supports her family through her business income.

Arezo, the second member of this group, has a shared business with her husband. She cleans fruits and vegetables and packages them, and her husband sells them from his cart in the market. This is the only business through which they support a family of 4 members.

Havzen has a tailoring business. She works in order to pay all the expenses of her family.

They have all requested a group loan of 42,000 Afghani to expand their businesses and compete the requirements. They would like to say "lots of thanks!" to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia S. is from the village of Owaon. She is 49 years old. Lilia is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates an agricultural business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years, with approximate average monthly earnings of 1,900 PHP for these activities.

In 2006, Lilia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets, livestock feed, and other supplies. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Lilia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the her family.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, livestock feed, and other supplies

loans.name: Nely

texts.en:
Nely L. is now 31 years old and happily married to her husband, Jerry L., now 35 years old and working as a construction worker. In their long years of marriage, they have been blessed with three kids: Nelly Rose, 12 years old; Jonnel, 6 years old, and Althea Jane, 3 years old. Her oldest child and second-oldest child are in primary level education. Their expenses for the schooling of their children will begin to rise, especially when their youngest child starts to go to school. So Nely and Jerry are starting to save for their future. Aside from the salary Jerry gets from his work, Nely manages a business that buys and sells different frozen foods and some assorted biscuits. Also, she is offering her services to customers that want to have a manicure or pedicure. All of her businesses contribute to covering their daily expenses as well as the expenses of their children in school, so Nely is really trying hard to improve them.

Since she joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she has properly utilized every loan that she has received for the improvement of her business. Now she will again use the loan that she will receive to buy different things needed for her businesses. She is really hoping that her business will continue to run.

Now one of Nely's dreams is to have their own house in the future for their family. For her children, she really wants them to finish their studies until college because, according to Nely, this is the only thing she can give to their children, a good education that they can use to fight against poverty.

loans.use: To finance all her businesses

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: This woman is a mother of 3 children. She was born in 1968 and lives in the Fuzuli region. Ten years ago, she started this orchard business. Now she needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy fertilizer and pesticides for improving her orchard business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
For the second time, 32-year-old Shirley T. is requesting a loan through ASHI. The said loan will be used to finance another small business she will be starting, which is farming. It will be managed by her husband, who is a farmer, while she manages her previously started business, which is duck raising and hog fattening. The ducks and hogs she raises are sold once they have grown.

Shirley wants to augment the income she gets out of her previous business by starting a business for her husband through the loan she is requesting. This way, she believes that she will be able to achieve her dream of having a house of their own, where all of her three children can live in comfort.

loans.use: To pay for the purchases needed for the rice production (planting) business

loans.name: Bahar Group

texts.en:
Najeba is the group leader of Bahart group. There are five members in this group. All of them would like to receive a loan for their own businesses.

Najeba and Shokarya want to take a loan for their carpentry business. Faryda and Shafeqa want to take a loan for their embroidery business. Bekam Saheb wants to take a loan for her tailoring business. They all want to buy necessary materials for their businesses.

They want to say this loan is very use full because it can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses and become stronger in their businesses and their lives. This group wants to thank this process of providing loans in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy materials for a carpentry business

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
Maricar R., 31 years old, lives in a poor community in Parola, Tondo, Manila—a shantytown at the edge of Manila Bay. Her husband, Gary, is a vendor like her. Two of their three children are now in elementary school, and the youngest is not yet in school.

Maricar’s general store has been in operation for eight years now. Her neighbors buy rice, grocery items, and other basic household necessities from her store. She is making more than 30,000 PHP a month in net revenue. She uses her profits to sustain daily family needs and support her children's education.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative, so she has applied for a new loan in the amount of 14,000 PHP to use as additional capital for the continuous growth of her business. She will restock on nonperishable grocery items and rice to sell at her store.

Maricar wishes to see her store grow into a mini-mart or a supermarket someday. She also dreams of a new house and lot for her family.

About CCT: The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missions in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for retail

loans.name: Estrellita

texts.en: Estrellita S. is from the town of Canunan, Guipos, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 45 years old, is married, and has one adult child. Estrellita owns and operates a business making and selling food, selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000.00 PHP a month. In 2008, Estrellita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Estrellita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita R. is a struggling mother of five children. Through her hard work and determination to bring them out of poverty, she was able to send the eldest four to college where they took vocational courses. Her small business enabled her to augment the income of her husband who is a motorcycle driver. Now, two of her children work in Manila and two have their own families.

For her youngest child, Bernardita wants to ensure her future by supporting her studies until she graduates from college. She believes that the only way she could make this dream of hers come true is through strengthening her small business and making it grow to increase the profits she makes from it. She therefore is requesting a loan through ASHI to be able to support her dream for her family through her farming business managed by her husband.

loans.use: To finance her farming and fishing businesses

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en: Arlene A. is from the village of Tagulalo, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 30 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Arlene owns and operates a business selling fish in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Arlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to improved and expand her business. Arlene is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay for the tuition of her children. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine A. is from the town of Canunan, Guipos, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 49 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Josephine owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Denise

texts.fr: H. Denise est née en 1969 à Adjarra, non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Denise vit depuis sa naissance à Adjarra et est mariée à DJOSSA Benoît, un mécanicien. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont certains seulement sont scolarisés. Denise et Benoît vivent ensemble avec leurs enfants. Denise vient en aide à son mari Benoît dans les charges de la famille. Denise n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis dix ans, Denise mène comme activité, la vente de divers (tomate, conserves, pâte alimentaire, etc.) et de mil à son domicile à Adjarra. Denise fait ses approvisionnements à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Dans le but d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et de satisfaire davantage sa clientèle, Denise sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Denise H. was born in 1969 in Adjarra, not far from Porto Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Denise has lived in Adjarra since she was born, and she is married to Benoît Djossa, a mechanic. The couple has four children, of which only some are in school. Denise and Benoît live together with their children. Denise helps her husband Benoît in providing for the family. Denise never went to school. For ten years, Denise has run a business selling various items (tomatoes, canned goods, food paste, etc.) and millet at her home in Adjarra. Denise obtains her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. With the goal of increasing her working capital and better satisfying her customers, Denise is seeking her first loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners).

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items and millet

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita P., 49, wants her hog-fattening and fishing businesses to become successful. They are the main income providers for her family, and she is requesting a larger amount of loan to finance their growth and sustainability.

Angelita’s husband, Maximo, manages their fishing business while Angelita takes care of their hog-fattening business and also sells her husband's fish. Profits from the businesses have enabled Angelita to send her eldest child to college to take a vocational course. Now, her second child is taking a course in care-giving and her youngest child is in a pre-school. Through her business she hopes to provide for her children's needs and education until they graduate from college and find jobs.

loans.use: To buy materials to repair fishing boat, with a small portion of the loan used to buy piglets

loans.name: 041 Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Chung Vũ K. (83) is a 37-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  Chung is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 041 (041 Quảng Hưng).

Chung is married and has one school-aged child.  To making a living, Chung is starting a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale.  Chung has been engaged in this business for over one year and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2007, Chung joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Chung successfully repaid a previous loan of 2.761.200 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND, which will be used to purchase more baby livestock to raise and sell.  The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Chung plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  H.  Thị Hoa (63) is a 29-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

2.  Đỗ Thị Dương (77) is a 55-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.

3.  Lê Thị Đảm  (78) is a 53-year-old female who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Chung Vũ K. (83) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoá.  Chung là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 041 (041 Quảng Hưng).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Chung thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 1 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Chung kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2007, Chung đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Chung đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 2.761.200 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  H.  Thị Hoa (63) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Đỗ Thị Dương (77) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  Lê Thị Đảm  (78) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda D. is from the village of Danao. She is 51 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Rosenda owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Rosenda has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Rosenda joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Rosenda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida P. is from the village of Dawo. She is 51 years old, married and has five children. Four of her children are adult-aged and the youngest is at school. To make a living, Zenaida owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Zenaida joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Lilian Wangu

texts.en: Lilian is married to Joseph and they have no children yet. She was introduced to KADET through existing clients, and has no previous credit history. Lilian has been in the business of selling new clothes for two years. With the loan she is acquiring, she intends to add to her stock of new clothes since demand is high because it is the high festive season (school holidays and Christmas holiday). Lilian operates her business out of a stall in an open market where there are many customers. With the extra profits, Lilian plans to open another stall and her hope is to sell clothes wholesale. Lilian believes she is very determined and hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase new clothes to sell at her stall in the market

loans.name: Oldokh

texts.en:
Oldokh B. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and five-year-old son in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His son, Temuujin, is in kindergarten, and his wife, Odontuya, helps B. with the family business.

B. manages a vegetable-trading business in his town. He sells a variety of vegetables which he grows on a two-hectare (5-acre) field that he owns.

B. started his vegetable-trading business in 2002 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). He has since found success and has built a stable business operation. He attributes his success to his good customer relationships and communication skills.

Today, B.’s working capital exceeds 2,000,0000 tugrugs (~1400 USD). He has used his earnings to purchase a motorcycle which he uses to travel to meet with his many customers and business partners.

For the future, B. plans to rent a stall at a local trading center to sell his vegetables. This will give him room to expand his product variety and customer base. He hopes his future earnings will allow him to buy a car and build a workplace for his business.

B. is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase fruit to sell along with his vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase fruit to sell along with his vegetables

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane B. strongly believes that attaining a higher level of education will lead her children to having a well compensated job or to a stable one. Although her six eldest children have stopped going to school, she still encourages them to go back. However, because of poverty and low income, she somehow understands the reason for her children’s decision.

Instead of succumbing to frustrations and disappointments, Mary Jane wants to grow her husband’s fishing business so as to increase the volume of fish she directly sells to people in their village and in the neighboring villages. Through this, their income will be increased and she will be able to support the education of her three youngest children until they graduate from college.

The loan she is requesting now is the greatest opportunity for her to change the pattern of life of her three remaining children. Also, she would love to prepare herself financially for the possibility that some of her older children will go back to school.

loans.use: To buy an engine and other materials for her husband's fishing boat

loans.name: Yulita

texts.en:
Yulita T. is from the town of Bag-ong, Guipos, Zambo. Del Sur. She is 53 years old, widowed and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Yulita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Yulita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Yulita joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC. Yulita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Dambarentsen

texts.en:
Dambarentsen B. is 40 years old and lives with her parents and 10-year-old son in Arhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her son, Barhuu, attends a local secondary school.

B. operates a machinery parts trading business in her town with the help of her brother. She started her business in 2005 with capital of 800,000 tugrugs (~560 USD). Over the years, she has gained much experience in her trade and always tries to grow and improve her business. She has built a stable business and a positive reputation among her customers, and today her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD).

B. is a very open-minded and hardworking person. Her main goal is to provide for her son's education and to help him become a good and responsible person. For the future, she hopes to expand her business, and is requesting a 3,800,000 tugrug loan to buy supplies for her machinery parts trading business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her machinery parts trading business

loans.name: Jane Wangui

texts.en:
Jane is married to Bernard and they have three children: Ian, Mark and Victor. Jane is hardworking and has been selling second-hand items for four years. She was introduced to Kiva partner KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history. With her loan, she intends to add to her stock of second-hand furniture and electronics.

Jane's business is strategically placed along a busy road and therefore is able to attract a good number of customers. With the extra profit Jane hopes to make, she plans to furnish her rental rooms, which are her other source of income. One day, Jane hopes to open a stall to sell her goods at market.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of microentrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add to her stock of second-hand furniture and electronics

loans.name: Felly

texts.en:
Felly L. is a typical mother who dreams of giving her children the kind of life they will enjoy for as long as they are young until they will have their own families someday. Loans she has requested through ASHI since her membership began in 1998 have enabled her to achieve partial fulfillment of her dream.

Felly has her own business which is embroidery. As years passed by, she made it grow and has made herself one of the famous woman in embroidering formal dresses: barong (a typical Filipino formal shirt for men) and Filipiñana (a typical Filipino dress for women).

Her profits have grown, yet regarding all her children’s financial needs for food, clothes, and education, her income as a single parent (after the death of her husband many years ago) is not enough. Though she has sent her three older children to a vocational course and has enabled them to graduate from it, she still has three children to work hard for until they graduate from college.

The loans Felly is requesting now and in the future will bring joy and fulfillment. For a 54-year-old woman like her, she has nothing to dream of but seeing her children enjoying things that life can offer aside from poverty.

loans.use: To buy materials she needs for her embroidery business

loans.name: Danzanhorol

texts.en: Danzanhorol Batbayar is 44 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in the Arkhangai province of central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). His youngest son currently attends a local secondary school. Batbayar operates a dairy trading business in his town. He started his business 12 years ago with a working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) and has built a stable operation over the years. Today, he is well established in the local business community and attributes his success to his strong customer base, communication skills and good accounting practices. Batbayar also has many reliable suppliers, many of whom sell exclusively to him. Today, his working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). Still, Batbayar hopes to own his own workspace which will allow him to serve more customers. He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan, which he will use to purchase more dairy products for his business.

loans.use: purchasing more dairy products

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Ma. Luisa I. is now 38 years old. She is happily married to Lenito I., who is 39 years old and currently works as a carpenter. They have several children: Melanie, 18 years old, Mary Anne, 15 years old, Abegail, 14 years old, Lenito Jr., 11 years old, and Nicole, 3 years old. Ma. Luisa and Lenito are distressed because their oldest daughter only has a low level of education due to poverty, which forced Melanie to stop her studies and help her parents to work so that all of her youngest siblings could continue to go to school. She is the oldest so she needs to make sacrifices for her siblings. Now Ma. Luisa doesn’t want this to happen again, so she is striving hard to earn enough income to cover all of their expenses.

Their sources of income are: Lenito I.'s salary and the sewing business that Ma. Luisa I. personally manages. It has been active for 10 years now and is still continuing to grow. When she joined the Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she always used the loans that she received to improve her business. This time, she will once again buy what she needs to make her business more productive.

Ma. Luisa’s dream is to make it possible for all of her children to complete their studies; to do this, she must make sure that her business grows. Consequently, she hopes that you will lend her money, with which she will buy a new sewing machine.

loans.use: purchasing a new sewing machine

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina V. is from the village of Danao. She is 54 years old. Catalina is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Catalina runs a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Catalina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Catalina joined PMPC in order to gain access to financial services that could help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Catalina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Catalina is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to further expand the business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Catalina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: investing in her fishing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Suppling his store with merchandise

loans.name: Urchig

texts.en: E. is 27 years old and lives with his mother in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. He and his mother live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). With the help of his sister, E. operates a traditional boots and clothing business in his town. He and his sister began their business with working capital of 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD); since then, their working capital has grown to reach 600,000 tugrugs (~420 USD). His dream is to keep expanding his business and to, eventually, be able to afford to build his own house. E. is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan in order so that he can purchase necessary fabrics and finishing materials for his clothes and shoes.

loans.use: purchasing fabrics and finishing materials for his clothes and shoes

loans.name: Modesta

texts.en:
Modesta T. is from the town of Bag-ong, Guipos, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 42 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Modesta owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Modesta has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 15,000.00 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2007, Modesta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Modesta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Modesta is requesting a new loan of 10,000.00 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Modesta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Havtgai

texts.en: H. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. Her son, who is 15, attends a local high school and her daughter, who is 3, stays at home. H.’s husband works for a construction company during the summer and fall and is a fuel stoker in the winter and spring. H. operates a grocery business in a rented shop in her town. She began her business in 1993 with the help of her husband and has become very established in the many years since. She began to plant her own vegetables in 2007 in order to supplement her business earnings and has become successful in that endeavor as well. She would like to expand her business even further in the future and is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT (700 USD) loan in order to purchase more products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr: H. Victorine est née en 1979 à Djèrègbé, village se trouvant à l'entrée de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Victorine est mariée à SOVI Mètohoué, un pêcheur. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, et réside à Gbokpa à Djèrègbé il y a dix ans déjà. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par les deux conjoints. Victorine n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis près de huit ans, Victorine vend des condiments de sauce (tomate, oignons, piments, huile de palme, etc.) et des friperies à son domicile. Victorine fait ses emplettes au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo et à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour accroître la taille de son activité et réaliser plus d'économie, Victorine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Victorine was born in 1979 in Djèrègbé, a village found at the entrance of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married to SOVI Mètohoué, a fisherman. The couple has four children who are all in school, and has been residing in Gbokpa in Djèrègbé for ten years already. Family expenses are covered jointly by the couple. Victorine has never attended school. For almost eight years, she has been selling sauce condiments (tomatoes, onions, chili peppers, palm oil, et.) and second-hand clothing at her home. She makes her purchases at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo and in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a former ALIDé client, having benefited from two loans, which have been repaid. To expand her business and to save more money, she’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sauce condiments and used clothing

loans.name: Zaur
