texts.en: Zaur was born in 1970 and lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has two children. Zaur operates a car repair business, and has been engaged in the business for five years. Now, he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy spare parts to improve and expand his business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Meri

texts.en:
Meri P. is 26 years old. She lives in Ijevan with her husband and a son. Since 2008 Meri has rented a shop where she conducts a food trade. Meri’s husband helps her in this business. From her income Meri bought furniture and other necessities for her house. 

Meri needs 900,000 AMD to buy a big lot of cereals and cognac for her shop. From her future income, Meri hopes to increase her business and keep a second shop. Meri is a first cycle borrower in “Nor Horizon.”

loans.use: To buy a big lot of cereals and cognac for trade

loans.name: Diane

texts.fr: V. Diane est née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Diane est mariée à HOUNGAVOU Pierre, un chauffeur, et est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à sa charge. Diane vit avec son conjoint et ses enfants à Gbokpa à Djèrègbé, village situé à l’entrée de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Diane vient en aide à Pierre dans les charges de la famille. Diane n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a de cela trois ans déjà que Diane vend du charbon de bois et de l’huile de palme à son domicile. Diane s’approvisionne au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Diane a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. En vue d’accroître la taille de son activité et de faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Diane sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
V. Diane was born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to HOUNGAVOU Pierre, a chauffeur, and is the mother of five children who are all in school. Four of the children are in her care. Diane lives with her spouse and her children in Gbokpa in Djèrègbé, a village located at the entrance of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Diane aids her husband with regard to family expenses. She has never attended school. For three years already, she has been selling charcoal and palm oil at her home. She stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She has benefited before from two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid. With the aim of expanding her business and coping with customer demands, she’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal and containers of palm oil

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Munkhzul

texts.en:
J. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His two older children attend a local secondary school, and his youngest child goes to kindergarten.

J.’s wife helps him with their meat retail business. He began his business in 2006 and since then, he has stabilized his operation and gained a lot of experience. He hopes to keep his business stable and grow it in the future so that he can afford to improve his family’s quality of life. He is requesting a loan of 600,000 tugrug (~420 USD) in order to purchase livestock for his business.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for his business

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora B. is from the city of Pagadian City. She is 40 years old. Leonora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Leonora owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Leonora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 9,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonora successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Leonora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jigjidsuren

texts.en:
L. is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in one of the ger districts on the outskirts of the city. Her two children, ages 15 and 13, both attend a local secondary school.

L. operates a noodle-producing shop with the help of her husband. They began the business in 2007 with no employees other than themselves. Since then, they have been able to hire 6 employees, and their working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~1750 USD). L. would like to keep growing her business and be able to hire even more people in the future so that this business not only helps her family, but the families of her employees. She is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) in order to purchase a large amount of flour used in the production of noodles.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of flour to make noodles

loans.name: Marusya

texts.en:
O. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two adult daughters in the Arkhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two daughters both attend university and her husband helps her with her business.

O. and her husband operate a meat retail business in the local market in their town. They began their business in 2004 with working capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD). After several years of hard work and a loyal customer base, their working capital now exceeds 800,000 tugrugs (~560 USD). She would like to expand their business in the future and own her own meat store. O. is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 tugrug (~840 USD) in order to purchase more meat to sell during the upcoming winter months.

loans.use: To purchase more meat to sell this winter

loans.name: Charles Ooko

texts.en: Charles is married to Pascaline and they have two children: Frodito and Elvins. Charles was introduced to KADET through existing clients and he has no previous credit history. He has been in the tailoring business for nine years. He will use this loan to add to his stock of fabric as this time of the year the demand is high due to the festive season. Charles' place of business is situated in an open air market where many customers get their produce. With the extra profits, he would like to make ready-made clothes and enter into the wholesale market. Charles' dream is to own his own house; he believes he is hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add fabric stock to his tailoring business

loans.name: Patrick Tom

texts.en:
Patrick is married to Hanna and they have no children yet.

Patrick was introduced to KADET by existing clients, and has no previous credit history. He has been in the business of selling water and shoes for seven years. He intends to use this loan to buy a motorbike so he can transport his water for sale in other locations and diversify his source of income.

Patrick's business is in a slum area, and the residents of the area are his customers. With the extra profits he will purchase a stock of shoes to sell.

Patrick's hopes are to own a minibus and use it for the transportation of people. He believes he is hardworking.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport his water and diversify his income

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta D. C. is from the village of San Antonio. She is 39 years old. Julieta is married and has 12 school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used for additional working capital for the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Julieta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children and improve the living conditions of her family.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Elshan

texts.en:
Elshan was born in 1971. He is married and has one child. His family lives in the Fuzuli region.

Elshan plays an accordion at weddings. He has been in this business for 5 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
At the age of 54, Yolanda is already widowed. She is now all by herself in providing for her family. Her partner now is her business, which supports her family in their everyday expenses. Her two children (Abigail, 31 years old, and Lea, 28 years old) now have their own families. Yolanda is now a grandmother who wants only for her grandchildren to finish their studies, unlike their mothers. That is why she does everything just to improve her business that has been her partner for many years.

Yolanda's business is the selling of different kinds of plastic and Styrofoam. She has run this business for 10 years now, and she continues to run it with the help of added capital from a loan that she received in Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) after joining that organization in 2000. Because she used the loan properly, she has already expanded the store into a much bigger one than before. Now she wants another loan to buy the things she needs in her business so that it will grow more.

Yolanda's dream is not for herself anymore, but for her grandchildren--for them to finish their studies so they can have a better life in the future. She plans to make her business continue to grow so that she will help her grandchildren with their educational expenses.

loans.use: For additional capital

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.en: Hikmat is single and lives in the Fuzuli region. He was born in 1984. This young man has been in this business for four years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy foodstuffs to improve his general store.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
Adelaida S. is from the town of Baclay, Tukuran, Zambo, Del Sur. She is 41 years old. Adelaida is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Adelaida owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Adelaida has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Adelaida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelaida successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Adelaida is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the  loan taken out by Adelaida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Hawa

texts.fr:
Madame  Hawa  H.  est âgée de 34 ans, mariée et mère  de 5  enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une famille traditionnelle  avec son mari, ses enfants et plusieurs autres ménages dans le quartier Darsalam  de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école moderne  pour des raisons familiales, (car issue d’une famille de chérifs, son père voyait en l’école une source de déperdition). Elle fréquenta  plutôt l’école coranique qu’elle l’abandonna également tôt. C’est ainsi qu’elle commença à faire des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa grande sœur  qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle décide  d’évoluer  seule, en optant pour la  vente de légumes, de tubercules et d’épices, au marché château depuis  maintenant 15 ans. Elle  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices,  elle  fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elle  est  en relation depuis 24 mois. Après  4 prêts solidaires correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Elle  compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 15 sacs de pommes de terres et 10 sacs d’oignons. Elle  s’approvisionne à Bamako. Madame  Hawa  H.  vend   au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle  compte réaliser un bénéfice de 45 000FCFA par mois. Le bénéfice réalisé lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce et de participer aux événements sociaux (mariage, baptême etc.)  Son vœu est d’avoir  une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Madam Hawa Haidara is 34 years old, married and the mother of 5 children. She lives in the traditional family with her husband, children and several other households in Darsalam neighborhood of Segou town( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Unable to attend modern school owing to family reasons( originally from a cheriff family, the father sees school as a source of waste). She rather attended a koranic school which she equally abandoned early. This is how she started to do income generating business by her elder sister who sold food ingredients. After several years of apprenticeship, she decided to develop alone, opting for the sale of vegetables, tubers and spices in the palace market 15 years ago. She has great reputation and major customers. With the intention to increase his business capital in order to make more profit, she turns toward Soro Yiriwaso she 's been in acquaitance with since 24 months ago. After 4 group loans having been repaid correctly, she is on her fisrt individual loan. She intends to use this loan to buy 15 bags of potatoes and 10 bags of onions. She gets her supplies in Bamako. Madam Hawa Haidara sells for cash and for credit to a clietele composed of women and men. She intends to make a monthly profit of 45 000FCFA. The profit will enable her increase her business capital and to participate in social events( mariage, baptism etc) Her wish is to have a house for renting.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of potatoes and onions

loans.name: Peter Maina

texts.en:
Peter is married to Rosemary and they have one child: Shantel. Peter was introduced to KADET through existing clients, and he has no previous credit history. He has been in the taxi business for one year and will use this loan to buy another motorbike for his transportation business.  His area of business is in a town center and he gets many customers who use motorbikes for short distance travel. With the extra profits, Peter willl purchase a piece of land and build rental houses as he aspires to be a landlord. He believes he is very determined and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for taxi services.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: M. Marie est née en 1974 à Djèrègbé, village situé à l’entrée de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Marie réside à Gbokpa à Djèrègbé depuis une douzaine d'année. Mariée à DOSSOU Avocèfohoun, un maçon, Marie est mère de cinq enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants ne sont pas scolarisés. Marie vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Marie n'a jamais fréquenté. C'est pourquoi depuis son jeune âge, Marie vend des ustensiles de cuisine (glacières, assiettes, bols en séries, casseroles, bassines, cuillères, etc.) de façon ambulante. Marie achète ses articles au marché Ounando à Porto-Novo. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Marie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
M. Marie was born in 1974 in Djèrègbé, a village located at the entrance of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She has been residing in Gbokpa in Djèrègbé for a dozen years. Married to DOSSOU Avocèfohoun, a mason, she is the mother of five children, of whom three are in her care. None of the children are in school. Marie comes to her husband’s aid with regard to family expenses. She never attended school. This is why she has from an early age been selling kitchen utensils (insulated containers, plates, nested bowls, pots, tubs, spoons, etc.) as she goes door-to-door. She purchases her goods at the Ounando market in Porto-Novo. She is a former ALIDé client, having benefited before from two loans, which have been repaid. To increase the size of her business and to satisfy the more and more numerous demands of her customers, she’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils (sets of plates and bowls)

loans.name: Rokia

texts.fr:
Madame Rokia  C.  est  âgée de 40 ans, elle est mère d’un enfant et vit dans une famille nucléaire avec son  époux et son enfant  dans le quartier  Lafiabougou  de la ville de  San, région de Ségou (quatrième région de administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas  eu la chance de faire de longue étude, elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus  depuis son jeune âge  qu’elle a appris d’elle même  sur le tas.  De nos jours  elle excelle  dans   la vente des produits de beauté, qu’elle embrassa  il y a 10 ans. 
C’est dans le but  d’augmenter son capital que Madame Rokia a fait recours  à Soro Yiriwaso  il  y ‘a   5 ans. 
Après  5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe)  tous payés correctement, elle est à son premier prêt  individuel.
Avec ce prêt elle compte, acheter un important stock de marchandises à Bamako et au Burkina Faso et effectue sa vente au grand marché de San dans sa boutique,  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Ces ventes se font  essentiellement au comptant. 
Avec  l’augmentation de son fond de commerce, elle compte sur un bénéfice  de 130 000 FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera comme suit : une partie pour le remboursement du prêt,  l’autre  partie pour les petites dépenses de famille et  investir  le reste dans son entreprise. 
Madame Rokia espère solliciter un financement plus important pour  lui permettre d’ouvrir une deuxième  boutique pour son  fils à San.
texts.en:
Ms. Rokia C. is 40 years old and the mother of a child.  She lives in a nuclear family with her husband and child in the Lafiabougou district of the city of San, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali).  Not having had the chance to attend school for long, she became interested at a young age in revenue-generating work, which she learned-by-doing on her own.  These days, she excels in selling beauty products, which she embraced ten years ago. With the goal of increasing her capital, Ms. Rokia turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago.  After five solidarity loans (group loans), all properly repaid, she is now on her first individual loan.  With this loan, she intends to purchase a major stock of merchandise in Bamako and in Burkina Faso and to make sales in her shop at the big market of San.  Her customers are composed of women and men.  These sales are essentially made in cash.   With the increase in her business capital, she plans on a profit of 130,000 francs CFA per month that she will use as follows:  a portion for repaying the loan, the other portion for sundry family expenses, and the remainder for investing in her enterprise.   She hopes to apply for larger loans enabling her to open a second shop for her son, in San.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products to sell

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa M. est une femme de 53 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de YAMATOGNE depuis 4 ans. Avec son prêt elle développe un petit restaurant dans lequel elle vend le petit déjeuné, cette activité lui permet de se procurer des bénéfices pour faire face aux charges quotidienne de sa famille.
texts.en:
Awa M. is a 53-year-old woman who is married and the mother of two children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de YAMATOGNE for four years. With her loan, she’s developing a small restaurant where she sells breakfast. This business enables her to bring in the profits for coping with day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To further her business

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus P. is from the town of Baclay, Tukuran Zambo Del Sur. She is 44 years old. Venus is married and has eight grown children. To make a living, Venus owns and operates a business selling specialty food products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately $275 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Venus joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venus has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Venus is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi de l’association Badenya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins  4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font la restauration et le petit commerce des produits divers  comme activités génératrices de revenus à Tominian il y’a environ 13 ans. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Badenya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et sont à leur premier prêt de groupe. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour la restauration et l’achat de produits divers.  Ces activités sont très rentables pour ces femmes qui effectuent leurs ventes au comptant, en détail et quelques à crédit. 
Les membres du groupe Benkadi comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000 FCFA à 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi of Badenya association is made up of married women of Tominian town, Segou region( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).They live in traditionnal families and have average age of 31 years and at least 4 children. The women of this group do catering and petty trading of various products as income generating businesses in Tominian for about 13 years. Concerned about making profit on their businesses, the members of group Benkadi of Badenya association decided to be part of the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year and are on their first group loan. The current loan will be used for catering and the purchase of various products. These businesses are very profitable for these women who do their sales by retail for cash and sometimes on credit. The members of group Benkadi intend to make a monthly profit of 10 000FCFA to 15 000FCFA each which will be used for the repayment of the interest on the loan and the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: John G.

texts.en: Thirty-five year old John G. C. is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to buy house building materials. John is married and has three children who are attending primary schools.

loans.use: Buy house building materials

loans.name: Brema

texts.en: Brema K. is forty years old and married with six children who are attending primary and secondary schools. He is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 for the first time from Kiva through SMT. Brema will use this loan to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school related charges for his children

loans.name: Musa

texts.en: Musa T. wants a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children. Musa is thirty-six years old and married to a businesswoman. They have five children, three of whom are in secondary schools and two in primary schools.

loans.use: Pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: Samson G. is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to invest in his wife’s business. He is married to a businesswoman and they have five children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Samson’s wife sells market food: rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), pepper, and so on. She has been in this business for five years.

loans.use: Invest in his wife's business

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine Ayiinakamiye is 36 years old. She is married and has seven children, ages 1 - 17. Vestine and her family live in the Burera District in the Northern Province of Rwanda, a 2-hour drive from Kigali, the capital of Rwanda.   

Vestine grows and sells potatoes. She employs three people in her centrally located business. Vestine is a seasoned entrepreneur with 5 years of experience in the potato industry. Her business is open every day from 6 AM to 4 PM. With the extra income that she hopes to earn from her loan, Vestine plans to continue to expand her business offerings and her enterprise. 

Credit from VFC and Kiva lenders help her to manage the cash flow uncertainties of her seasonal business by adding to her working capital. Also, she will purchase more and different varieties of potatoes to sell to her customers. Vestine is requesting her 5th loan from Vision Finance Company. All of her previous loans were repaid on time and in full.

Vestine thanks VFC and Kiva for their support of her business.

loans.use: To expand the quantity and variety of potatoes that she sells

loans.name: Sedeqa Sameira Group

texts.en:
Ghullam Mayedine is the leader of the Sedeqa Sameira group, which consists of seven members. All of these individuals would like to receive funding for their respective businesses. To illustrate, Sedeqa and Tooba are seeking a loan for their tailoring business because they would like to expand the business and need a loan to do so. Meanwhile, Ghullam Mayedine and M. W. are requesting a loan for their general store business because they need to purchase additional goods. Khadeja and Nafesa would like a loan for their weaving business, while Sameira wants a loan for her beading business because she needs to purchase necessary materials for her shop in order to expand the business.

They explain that these loans will be extremely useful because the loan proceeds would enable them to expand and improve their businesses. They sincerely thank everyone from Kiva for their support.

loans.use: To expand and improve their respective businesses

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya de l’association Horonya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 33 ans et au moins  5 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce des produits divers à Tominian il y’a environ 15 ans. Elles vendent des cosmétiques, des tissus, des céréales et autres. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Danaya  de l’association Horonya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Ce groupe est à son premier prêt avec l’institution.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat des produits divers de commerce.  
Ces activités sont très rentables pour ces femmes qui font leurs ventes en détail au marché de Tominian. 
Les femmes du groupe Danaya comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000 FCFA à 20.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Danaya of Horonya association is made up of married women of Tominian town, Segou region ( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and have average age of 33 years and at least 5 children. The women of this group do petty trading of various products in Tominian for about 15 years. They sell cosmetics, fabrics, cereals and other items. To make profit on their businesses, members of group Danaya of Horonya association decided to be part of the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year. This group is on its first loan with the institution. The current loan will be used to purchase various products for trading. These businesses are profitable for these women who make sale by retail in the market of Tominian. The women of group Danaya intend to make a monthly profit of 15 000FCFA to 20 000FCFA each which will be used for repayment of interest on loans and the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma P. is from the town of Baclay, Tukuran, Zambo, Del Sur. She is 45 years old and married with four school-age children. To make a living, Elma owns and operates a fishing business. She harvests and sells farm-raised fish in the local community. Elma has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately $225 month from these activities.

In 2008, Elma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Elma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Mary Wacera

texts.en: Mary Wacera K. is married and has three children.  She runs her family business, which is selling milk to local people and private schools.  Their greatest challenge is lack of storage facilities for when there is an excess supply of milk.  She is using her KES 20,000 loan to buy a cooling machine.  In the future, she wants to be a supplier in Kitengela and Mlolongo.  Mary describes herself as hardworking, polite, principled and friendly.  She dreams of educating her grandchildren and building a home.

loans.use: To buy a cooling machine.

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita C. is from the village of San Pedro. She is a 65-year-old widow with five grown children. To make a living, Bernardita owns and operates a food stall in the local community where she sells fish. She has been engaged in her business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $43 a month from these activities.

In 2006, Bernardita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernardita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Bernardita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used for additional working capital. This will be her sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Djekadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djekadi de l’association Miniankaton est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 25 ans et au moins  3 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce d’articles divers à Tominian il y’a environ 10 ans. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Djekadi de l’association Miniankaton ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur premier prêt.   
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat  d’articles  divers de commerce.  
Ces activités sont très rentables pour ces femmes qui effectuent leur vente en détail et à une clientèle essentiellement féminine. 
Les membres du groupe Djekadi comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 10 000 FCFA à 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Djekadi of the Miniankaton Association is made up of married women of Tominian town, Segou region( fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) They live in traditional families and have average age of 25 years and at least 3 children. The women of the group do petty trading of various items in Tominian for about 10 years. To make profit on their businesses, members of group Djekadi of the Miniankaton Association decided to be part of the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso with which they are on their first loan. The current loan will be used to purchase various items for trading. These businesses are very profitable for these women who sell by retail and to mainly female customers. The members of group Djekadi intend to make a monthly profit of 10 000FCFA to 15 000FCFA each which will be used for the repayment of interest on the loan and the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Fatou Efa

texts.fr: Fatou Efa Sané est âgée de 57 ans elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc villageois de YAMATOGNE depuis 6 ans et demi, elle y a reçu 11 prêts qui lui ont permis jusqu'à aujourd'hui de développer une activité de vente de crème glacée. Elle participe activement à la prise en charge des dépenses quotidienne de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou Efa Sané is 57 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She has been a member of Banc Villageois de YAMATOGNE for 6½ years and has received from it eleven loans, which enabled her thus far to develop her business selling ice cream. She participates actively in meeting day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her ability to self-finance

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is 24 years old and single. He lives with his parents and four siblings. He started his business as a way to look after himself and his family. Mohammed owns a small store with various products such as mirrors, paintings, and other decorations. Lately, Mohammed has seen an increase in his number of clients, and he needs a $2000 loan to buy merchandise so he can provide a greater variety of products for his clients. He appreciates your belief in him and your support in improving and expanding his business.

loans.use: Buy more merchandise

loans.name: Josephine

texts.fr: H. Josephine est née en 1976 à Adjarra, village situé non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Josephine vit depuis sa naissance à Honvié à Adjarra. Mariée à HOUNTON Ablo un commerçant, Josephine est mère de quatre enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. En plus de ses enfants, Josephine a un enfant à sa charge. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Josephine n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Depuis 10 ans, Josephine vend de l'huile à moteur à la devanture de sa maison. Josephine vend également des boissons par le système de distribution. Josephine s'approvisionne à Comé et au Nigéria, État voisin du Bénin. Josephine sollicite un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé pour accroître la taille de son activité et satisfaire plus sa clientèle.
texts.en:
H. Josephine was born in 1976 in Adjarra, a village located near Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of the Republic of Benin. Since birth, she has been living in Honvié in Adjarra. She is married to HOUNTON Ablo, a merchant, and is the mother of four children. Some of them are in school. In addition to these children, she has another child to support. The couple covers family expenses jointly. Josephine never attended school. For ten years, she has been selling motor oil at the entrance of her house. She also sells beverages through the distribution system. She stocks up in Comé and in Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin. She’s requesting an initial loan from ALIDé for expanding her business and for satisfying her customers more.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy containers of motor oil and cases of drinks

loans.name: Yusif

texts.en: Yusif lives in the Fuzuli region. He is married and has three children. Ten years ago he started a cattle-breeding business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy five calves for improving his cattle-breeding business.

loans.use: to buy five calves

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.en:
Emiliana G., 63 years old and married to Lorenzo G., is the mother of two children, Rolando, now 37 years old and working as a fish pond operator and Olivia, 36 years old and working as a teacher. Both of them now have their own families, so even though the children now have salary coming from their work, Emiliana does not oblige them to give her money because she knows that they need it for their children. So the couple is working for themselves, although sometimes they receive money from the children. The variety store business they have been operating for the past seven years is their main source of income, and they also sell cell phone loads and some fishing equipment.

Emiliana is now requesting her second loan from Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) which she will use to purchase things needed in her variety store. She wants to improve this business in order to increase the income it provides for their everyday living. Emiliana is also really hoping that her business will grow so that instead of her children helping them, she will be able to help them, especially in the schooling of her grandchildren.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Hermisa

texts.en:
Hermisa A. is from the town of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zambo. Del Sur. She is 38 years old. Hermisa is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Hermisa owns and operates a clothing business, providing new clothing services to local community members. Hermisa is just starting this business.

In 2009, Hermisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hermisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fabrics and materials. Hermisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Hermisa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette P. is from the village of Guinabot, Sapang Dalaga. She is 39 years old. Bernadette is married and has one infant. To make a living, Bernadette raises cattle for sale. Bernadette is just starting this business.

In 2009, Bernadette joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bernadette has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Bernadette is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional animals. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Bernadette from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional animals

loans.name: Nakitto

texts.en:
M. is 25 years old and married with four children between the ages of 3 and 8 years old. All of her children go to school. She resides and owns a two-room house, where she is staying with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. M. takes care of additional family members as well.  

M. sells charcoal in Nalukolongo and doesn’t pay for transport costs to and from shopping because she buys from her home. On average, she receives three customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business ten years and has been with MCDT two years servicing her fifth loan, working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and buying medication. Her challenges include defaulters and thieves. 

M. wants to use this loan to buy more bags/sacks of charcoal  She is aspiring to see her business grow stronger and to be able to start buying charcoal directly from producers, as well as to build a self sustained restaurant.

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djekafo de l’association Horonya est composé de dix femmes toutes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins  6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font comme activité le petit commerce d’articles         divers  tels, le riz, le poisson, le tissu, le savon, les haricots etc. à Tominian il y’a environ 17 ans. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Horonya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Ils sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution.    
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat d’articles  divers de commerce auprès des grossistes de la place. Ces activités d’achat et de vente sont très rentables pour ces femmes du groupe Djekafo qui vendent leurs marchandises au comptant en détail et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Les membres du groupe Djekafo comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000 FCFA à 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Djekafo group belonging to the Horonya Association is composed of 10 women, all married, from the town of Tominian, Ségou region, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families and have an average age of 31 and on average, 6 children each.

The women of this group have been selling various small items such as rice, fish, cloth, soap, dried beans, etc. in Tominian for about 17 years.

In order to make their businesses more productive, the member of the Djekafo group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year. They are on their first loan with the institution.

This loan will be used to buy items for resale from local wholesalers. Their commercial businesses bring in a good income for the Djekafo members who sell their goods for cash, retail, and for credit to a diverse and varied clientele.

Each of the members of the Djekafo group expects to make a monthly profit of 10,000 to 15,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Adelarda

texts.en:
Adelarda M. is from the town of D'Ban, Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 69 years old. Adelarda is widowed and has five adult children. To make a living, Adelarda sells agricultural items. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling plants, seedlings and young crops to local farmers. Adelarda has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Adelarda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelarda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 70,000 PHP from PMPC. Adelarda is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Adelarda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nila

texts.en: Nila T. is from the  village of Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old, married and blessed with two school-age children. Mrs. T. is a member of PMPC, having joined August 8, 2006. She  owns and  operates a business making and selling a variety of food products in  the  local community. She has been engaged in her business for more than one year, earning a monthly net income of 1,500 PHP. Currently, she's requesting her sixth cycle loan in the amount of 14,900 PHP for the  purpose of additional capital for her existing business.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Miniankaton sont tous des femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, une préfecture de la région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce d’articles divers à Tominian tels les produits alimentaires, la lingerie etc. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Miniankaton ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit  de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, ils sont à leur premier prêt.   
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat d’une importante quantité de : divers condiments alimentaires et de céréales.  Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des grossistes de la place et des producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes en détail et au comptant au grand marché de Tominian à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Les membres du groupe Djekafo comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel de 15 000 FCFA à 22 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The four members of the Djekafo group belonging to the Miniankaton association are all married women from the town of Tominian, a prefecture of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and have an average age of 30 and on average, at least 6 children each.

The women of this group sell various small items in Tominian, such as foodstuffs, underwear, etc. In order to make their businesses more productive, the members of this Djekafo group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan.

This loan will be used to buy a large quantity of various condiments and cereals for resale. They buy from local wholesalers and from farmers and make their sales retail and for cash, at the big open-air market of Tominian, to a clientele composed essentially of women.

Each of the members of the Djekafo group expects to make a monthly profit of 15,000 to 22,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Gull Andam Parye Group

texts.en:
There are four members in this group, which is known as Gull Andam parye. They are seeking to receive funding for their respective businesses, so they are requesting a group loan in the amount of 40,000 Afghani ($825).

Specifically, Gull Andam and Parye would like a loan for their bakery business because they are hoping to open a new shop. Meanwhile, Mohammad Uasof and Fada Mohammad are requesting a loan for their general store business as they need to purchase certain necessary materials for their shop (they note that they have a lot of clients). They express their deep gratitude to all lenders of AFSG and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials for their respective businesses

loans.name: Bebian

texts.en:
Bebian E. is from the village of Magsaysay, Sibutad Zamboanga Del Norte. She is 49 years old. Bebian is married and has three school-age children. To make a living, Bebian owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Bebian has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Bebian joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bebian is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Bebian from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of raw ingredients for making food

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Airene

texts.en:
Airene T. is from the town of Motosawa, Dumalinao, ZDS. She is 30 years old. Airene is married and has three young children. To make a living, Airene owns and operates a business raising crops. She plants and harvests fruits and vegetables for sale. Airene has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Airene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Airene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Airene is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Airene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 46-year-old widow with four children between the ages of 22 and 28 years old. None of children goes to school. Alice resides in, and owns, a two-room house where she is staying with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Alice takes care of additional family members as well.  

Alice sells secondhand shoes in Owino Market and pays for transport costs to and from work and transportation expenses because she buys from her place of work. On average she receives three customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business ten years and with MCDT for two years, servicing her fifth loan, working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding her family and buying medication. Her challenges include defaulters and thieves. 

Alice wants to use this loan to buy more secondhand shoes. She is hoping to see her business grow bigger and to be able to start buying directly from Kenya and Mombasa.

loans.use: To buy shoes for resale

loans.name: Eugénie

texts.fr: K. Eugénie est née le 07 Février 1968 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à MIDODJIHO Félix, un dessinateur, Eugénie est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. La famille vit depuis 10 ans à Hinkoudé, un quartier de Porto-Novo. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par Eugénie et Félix. Eugénie n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Depuis 10 ans déjà, elle s’est livrée à la vente de nourriture (sauce de mouton accompagnée de l’akassa, aliment fait à base d’amidon de maïs, et du poisson). Eugénie fait ses approvisionnements au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, et vend sa nourriture à Koutongbé, un quartier de Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Eugénie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir sa clientèle.
texts.en:
K. Eugénie was born on February 7, 1968 in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Married to MIDODJIHO Félix, a draftsman, Eugénie is the mother of three children, all enrolled in school. For 10 years, the family has been living in Hinkoudé, a district of Porto-Novo. Family living expenses are a shared responsibility of Eugénie and Félix.

Eugénie never went to school. For 10 years, she has been selling cooked food (mutton stew with 'akassa', a dish made of cornstarch, and fish). Eugénie buys her ingredients in the market Ouando in Porto-Novo, and sells her food in Koutongbé, a district of Porto-Novo. She has been a client of ALIDé for some time and has had two loans which have been correctly reimbursed. Eugénie is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to add to her working capital and grow her clientele.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of mutton and condiments such as tomatos, onions, hot peppers, etc.

loans.name: Khalid

texts.en: This young man is single. He lives in Fuzuli region. He was born in 1987. Khalid has been in the sheep breeding business for two years. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy 15 sheep for improving his sheep breeding business.

loans.use: To buy 15 sheep

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy L. wishes to improve her family’s standard of living by making her business grow and become stable. Through ASHI, she can access loans to finance her business. Since the time of her membership, Nancy had been trusted with several loans. She has proven her worth from then to now. With her determination to become successful in running a business, she is confident to request a much larger amount. Nancy has wanted to fulfill her ambition for her family through her business, especially her aspiration to send her eight children to college. Two of them are soon to graduate, while some are in high school and elementary school.

Despite the hardships Nancy faces every day, she remains determined and persistent because of the love and support she receives from her husband and children. With loans she can access through ASHI, Nancy will not succumb to usurious money lenders that offer large loan amounts without any requirement aside from high interest rates.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Preciosa S. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 62 years old. Preciosa is widowed and has two adult children. To make a living, Preciosa owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. Preciosa has been engaged in her business for more than ten years with an approximated average monthly earnings of 1,800 PHP.

In 2008, Preciosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Preciosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets, livestock feed and other supplies. Preciosa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more livestock feed and supplies. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Preciosa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Fayida Group

texts.fr:
Fayida est un groupe de l’association Djekadi composé de sept femmes mariées  de la ville de Tominian, une préfecture de la région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies avec en moyenne 28 ans et  4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font la restauration et le commerce d’articles divers. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Fayida de l’association Djekadi ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur premier prêt. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat de condiments alimentaires, du riz et bien d’autres ingrédients qui rentrent dans le cadre de la restauration. 
Cette activité  de restauration leur est très rentable et elles vendent essentiellement au comptant à une clientèle composée de routiers. 
Les membres du groupe Fayida comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice de 15 000 FCFA à 30 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
'Fayida' is a group belonging to the Djekadi Association, made up of 7 married women from the town of Tominian, a prefecture of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional extended families and have an average age of 28 and on average, 4 children each.

The women of this group sell cooked food and various retail items. In order to make their businesses more productive, the members of this Fayida group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan.

This loan will be used to buy condiments, rice, and a lot of other ingredients for cooked food. This catering business earns them a good income, and they sell essentially for cash to a clientele composed of transporters.

Each of the members of the Fayida group expects to make a monthly profit of 15,000 to 30,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for making cooked food to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
This is Jocelyn C., a 39-year-old store owner from Pasay City.  She lives with her husband, Noel, 42, a computer animator, and their three children, two of whom go to school.

Jocelyn has been running her general store for ten years now, and due to insistent consumer demand, she also started selling electronic load credits for mobile phones.  She now earns close to 10,000 PHP a month.  

She became a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2002.  She is now applying for a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP for the continuous operation of her business. She will buy a more grocery items and additional refreshments (soft drinks). Some of the funds will be used for her home renovation.

It has been her dream to own a new house and property for her kids.


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries

loans.name: Eudisa

texts.en:
Eudisa B. together with her husband and children hope that their fishing and wholesale fish selling business will grow and become sustainable. Aside from Eudisa’s dream of helping her three unemployed children have their own source of income, she also wants her business to generate employment outside of family members. Above all this, she wants her youngest daughter to graduate from high school and college to be able to find herself a better paying and stable job in the future. 

Eudisa believes that her dreams will forever be just a vision without access to a loan. Therefore, through her membership in ASHI, she is requesting a much larger amount to finance the growth of her business, and her profits will be used to improving their standard of living as well as to help people in need of job.

loans.use: To increase the volume of fish she buys and sells and to finance her fishing business

loans.name: Kanouya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kanouya de l’association Dounkafa est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, une des préfectures de la région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 28 ans et au moins 3 enfants.
Les femmes du  groupe Kanouya  font la restauration et le commerce d’articles divers comme activité génératrices de revenus. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Kanouya de l’association Dounkafa ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle ils sont à leur premier prêt. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat de condiments alimentaires, du riz et d’autres ingrédients pour la restauration qui est très rentable pour ces femmes. 
Elles vendent leurs plats alimentaires généralement au comptant et à une clientèle riche te variée.
Les femmes du groupe Kanouya comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 15.000 FCFA à 30.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
'The Kanouya group belonging to the Dounkafa Association, made up of married women from the town of Tominian, a prefecture of the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and have an average age of 28 and on average, at least 3 children each.

The women of this Kanouya group sell cooked food and various retail items in order to earn income. To make their businesses more productive, the members of this Kanouya group decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan. This loan will be used to buy condiments, rice, and a lot of other ingredients for cooked food, a business which earns these women a good income. They sell their cooked dishes generally for cash to a varied clientele. Each of the members of the Kanouya group expects to make a monthly profit of 15,000 to 30,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for making cooked food to sell

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina N. is from the town of Pinig, Dumalinao, ZDS. She is 41 years old. Faustina is married and has six school-age children. To make a living, Faustina owns and operates a business raising crops. She plants and harvests rice for sale. Faustina has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Faustina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Faustina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Faustina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Faustina from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad K. is a 45-year-old father of six children (all of whom attend secondary school). He and his wife are both businesspeople, and Mohamad is seeking a loan in order to invest money in his wife's business, which is selling rice, palm oil, pepper, and other Sierra Leonean staple goods. With a loan of SLL 1,000,000, Mohamad and his wife can expand her inventory and bring in more income for their family.

loans.use: Expansion of business

loans.name: Abdul Y.

texts.en: Abdul K. is a 47-year-old businessman. He and his wife have seven children, one of whom is married and six who attend school, ranging from the nursery to secondary level. Abdul is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from SMT and Kiva lenders in order to help him pay the school fees and related costs for his children.

loans.use: School fees and related expenses

loans.name: Moutian Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Moutian de l’association Dori est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 28 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font entre autres comme activités génératrices de revenus, la couture, la restauration, la fabrication de jus de fruits et le commerce d’articles divers tels les céréales etc. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Moutian de l’association Dori ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur premier prêt. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat des ingrédients rentrant dans la restauration à Tominian ville. Elles s’approvisionnent auprès des grossistes et des forains et effectuent leur vente très généralement au comptant. Elles sont très sollicitées et appréciées. 
Les femmes du groupe Moutian comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice de 10.000 FCFA à 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Moutian group of the Dori Association is composed of married women from the town of Tominian, Segou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and have an average age of 28 and at least 6 children each. The women from this group, in order to earn income, do sewing, sell cooked food, make and sell fruit juice, among other things, and sell other items such as cereals.

WIshing to make their businesses more productive, the members of the Moutian group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso, with whom they are on their first loan.

This loan will be used to buy ingredients used for cooked food in the town of Tominian. They buy their ingredients from wholesalers and from weekly market vendors, and they make most of their sales for cash. They are much sought after and appreciated. Each of the women of the Moutian group expects to make a profit of 10,000 to 15,000 F CFA which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and for current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for making cooked food to sell

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad S. is a 37-year-old trader. He and his wife are in business together, and they also have three children, all of whom attend school. Mohamad is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 in order to pay school fees and related expenses for his children.

loans.use: Pay school fees and expenses

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth C., 50, who lives and does business in Parola, Binondo, Manila. She lives with her husband, Dionisio, an electrician helper, and their only child amongst the poor families in this shanty town.

Elizabeth has a food stall in a nearby market selling vegetables, spices and seasonings. Her child helps her wait on buying customers. She earns 20,000 PHP a month, which she saves to be able to buy a cargo vehicle she can use to purchase her items from the vegetable depot.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005.  Elizabeth is now on her 16th loan cycle. She is requesting a new loan from the cooperative in the amount of 29,000 PHP as additional capital. With this new additional capital, she can purchase more assorted vegetables for her business.

She hopes to acquire another food stall in a neighboring market. 



About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To buy additional vegetables and seasoning

loans.name: Osman

texts.en: Osman S. is a 38-year-old man who has been in business for six years selling market foods such as palm oil, rice, and peppers. He has three children, two of whom attend school, while the third is too young for school. Osman is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 in order to invest in his business, expand his inventory, and grow his income.

loans.use: Expansion of business inventory

loans.name: Santigie

texts.en: Santigie S. is a 45-year-old businessman, who lives with his wife and his seven children. All seven children are currently enrolled in primary and secondary schools, and Santigie is seeking a loan of SLL 1,000,000 from SMT and the Kiva lenders in order to continue paying their school fees and school-related expenses.

loans.use: School fees for his children

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine U. is now 35 years old and happily married to her partner in life Francis U., who is 36 years old and currently working as an office clerk. They were blessed with 3 children: Franz Joseph, 8 years old; Tricialinne, 5 years old; and Nicole, 2 years old. According to Josephine, she wants to save for the education of her children while her children are not spending too much for their education today. So even though her husband has a salary from his work, she finds alternative ways to earn income. This was why she started her variety store business that has been running for 1 year now.

When she joined the Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she used the loan that she received to buy things that she needed for her business. Now her loan will also be used to buy necessary things for the improvement of her business.

One hope of Josephine's is that through their perseverance, and with the help of ASHI, they will change the life that they have right now.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Sham-E-Khamosh Group

texts.en:
This is the Sham-e-Khamosh group, which consists of three members, all of whom live in the 8th district of Kabul, Afghanistan. Fahima, pictured in the middle, is the group leader.

Fahima is married with four children (two sons and two daughters), all of whom are currently in school. For more than ten years now, she has earned a living as a tailor. She is requesting a loan to buy a new sewing machine, as well as threads, scissors, and other necessary materials, in order to sew high-quality clothes for her customers. M. Rafee seeks a loan for his retail shop because he would like to expand his inventory. And last but not least, M. Samy would like a loan for his fruit cart shop because he wants to improve his business in order to better support his family members. Collectively, they are seeking a (group) loan in the amount of 30,000 Afghani ($625), and they appreciate the continued support from Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To improve their respective businesses by purchasing necessary materials

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, who are all in school. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to support her husband financially to provide for the family.

Agnes is a trader. She trades in ladies underwear. She procures the goods from nearby towns and hawks to sell in her community. Agnes has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hoping to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy ladies underwear

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is 54 years old and married with two children aged 18 and 23 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a five-roomed house where she is staying with five people. The family has access to electricity but has no piped water. Prossy takes care of additional family members.

She sells crafts like mats and tablecloths in Makerere Kikoni and pays for transport costs to and from shopping. Prossy sells six days a week. On average she receives 10 customers a day. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business eight years and with MCDT for eight years.

She is now servicing her twentieth loan and working with the same group mates. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication. Her challenges include defaulters and crafts like mats and tablecloths. She aspires to see her business grow stronger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more crafts and raw materials for making crafts.

loans.name: Parissi Group

texts.fr:
