Le groupe Parissi de l’association Dori est composé de 6 femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, une des préfectures de la  région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec  en moyenne 26 ans et au moins 4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe Parissi font l’achat et la vente d’articles divers tels l’arachide,  les condiments alimentaires, les boissons de fabrication locales, les tissus etc. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs activités, les femmes du groupe Parissi de l’association Dori ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, elles sont à leur premier prêt. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter une grande quantité d’articles divers de commerce auprès des grossistes et forains. Elles effectuent leurs ventes en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle riche et variée. 
Les membres du groupe Parissi comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel 15 000 à 18 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille. 
NB : Alice Dembélé est absente de la photo pour raison de maladie.
texts.en:
The Parissi group of the Dori association is composed of 6 married women from the city of Tominian, one of the prefectures in the Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and average 26 years of age and at least 4 children. The woman of the Parissi group buy and sell various products such as peanuts, food condiments, locally made beverages, fabrics, etc.

Eager to make their businesses profitable, the women of the Parissi group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their first loan. The loan will be used to buy a large quantity of various products from wholesalers and fair vendors. They sell retail, for cash and on credit, to a very diverse clientele.

The members of the Parissi group intend to turn a monthly profit of XOF 15'000 to 18'000 (ca US$ 35 to 42) each, to be used to repay the loan and to provide for the daily expenses of their families.

NB: Alice Dembélé was ill when the photo was taken, and is therefore not in it.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various products such as peanuts, food condiments, locally made beverages, fabrics, etc.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is thirty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Mariama works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a petty trader. She sells yams. She procures them from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Mariama has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy  yams for resale

loans.name: Nafissatou

texts.fr: Nafissatou B. est une femme de 55 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de YAMATOGNE depuis 6 ans et demi et y a eu de belles performances. Avec son crédit elle développe une activité de vente de poisson frais. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer à la prise en charge quotidienne de la famille.
texts.en:
Nafissatou B. is a 55-year old woman, she is married and she is the mother of 4 children who are all still in her care. She has been a member of the Yamatogne village bank for the past 6 and a half years and she has had successful experiences. With her loan she will invest in her business selling fresh fish. Her earnings allow her the ability to contribute to the daily needs of her family.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Fati is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to eight children. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Fati works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a petty trader. She sells a local vegetable called ‘dawadawa’. It is used to prepare soup. She procures the vegetables from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Fati has been in business for over sixteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy vegetables

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sabali de l’association Djekadi est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et  ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins  4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce des produits divers (savon, fonio haricot, poisson) et la restauration à Tominian il y’a environ 15 ans. Le petit commerce et la restauration sont des activités qui marchent bien dans cette zone.
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Sabali de l’association Djekadi ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt.
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat d’une importante quantité  de produits divers. 
Les membres du groupe Sabali comptent réaliser chacun un bénéfice mensuel de 10 000 FCFA à 15 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Sabali group of the Djekadi association is composed of married women from the city of Tominian in the Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and average 31 years of age and at least 4 children.

The women of the group have been selling various products (soap, fonio, beans, fish) and doing food catering for approximately 15 years in Tominian. These types of businesses work well in this area. To make their businesses profitable, the members of the Sabali group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are seeking their first loan. The loan will be used to buy a large quantity of various products.

The members of the Sabali group count on turning a monthly profit of XOF 10'000 to 15'000 (ca US$ 24 to 32) each, to be used to repay the loan and to provide for the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various products

loans.name: Sherly

texts.en:
Sherly M., 31 years old, is a construction worker’s wife. Her family lives in Silang, Cavite. They have one child.

Sherly, understanding the hardships in life and knowing that her husband has to literally punish himself physically to earn a living, applied for membership with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative last year to get a loan as additional investment for her newly opened general store. Over time, her store has grown steadily so that she now earns P6,000 a month. She continues to infuse additional capital into her store from her profits and savings.

She is now on her 4th loan with CCT and has recently applied for a new loan amounting to P11,000. She will use the funds to purchase more items to sell at her general store.

Her utmost dream is to manage her child’s education well.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Mayi

texts.en:
Mayi is 28 years old and married with three children aged between 5 and 10 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she is staying with five people. The family has access to electricity but no piped water. Mayi takes care of additional family members.

Mayi owns a restaurant in Makerere Kikoni and pays for transport costs to and from shopping. Mayi works six days a week. On average she receives 20 customers a day. She works on the outskirts of Kampala. She has been in this business for four years and with MCDT eight years, and she is servicing her tenth loan, working with the same group-mates.

Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and buying medications. Her challenges include defaulters and increasing costs of foodstuffs. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow stronger and starting selling on a wholesale basis only.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Sinignèsigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèsigui de l’association Badenya est composé de femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe font le petit commerce d’articles divers (tels le poisson, le tissu, le savon, les céréales etc.) à Tominian il y’a environ 15 ans. 
Pour rentabiliser leurs activités, les membres du groupe Sinignèsigui de l’association Badenya ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui ils sont à leur premier prêt.    
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour l’achat d’un important stock de produits divers auprès de grossistes. Ces activités sont très rentables pour ces femmes qui vendent en détail surtout. 
Les membres du groupe Sinignèsigui comptent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel de 10.000 FCFA à 17.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Sinignèsigui of the association Badenya is composed of married women of the city of Tominian, region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women live in traditional families and average 31 years of age and 6 children each.  For about fifteen year in Tominian, the women of the group have had small businesses involving a variety of goods (such as fish, cloth, soap, grains, etc.) To make their work profitable, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their first loan.  The current loan will be used to buy a major stock of various goods from wholesale merchants.  These businesses are very worthwhile for these women who sell especially at the retail level.  The group members each plan on realizing an average monthly profit of 10,000 to 17,000 francs CFA that will be used for paying the loan interest and for common family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods (fish, fabrics, soaps, beans, etc.)

loans.name: Makhsuda

texts.en:
A. Makhsuda is 45 years old. She is divorced and the mother of 3 children. For 20 years now, Makhsuda has been selling clothing. She sells socks for men and children in the central local market. Makhsuda spends the income from her business for educating of her children as she is dreaming that her children will have a higher education.

Makhsuda has been provided with the loans by IMON for 4 years already . For the entire period of time she has shown herself to be an accurate client. Today she is requesting 5000 Somoni ($1150 USD) to purchase new goods for resale. Makhsuda promises to pay the loan back on time and thanks all supporting her.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is twenty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to one daughter who is in school. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Margaret works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a hairdresser by profession. She has her shop by the roadside in her community and currently has one apprentice. She wants a loan to buy materials like artificial hair, pomade, etc.

Margaret has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy more working materials to improve her services.

loans.use: To buy artificial hair, etc.

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
A. Dilorom’s passion lies with children. A married mother of four, Dilorom opened her business selling men’s clothing with the goal of providing a better standard of living for her family. For the past 15 years, Dilorom has successfully operated her business at the market.

With her profits, she not only has improved the living standards for her children but she has been able to support her elderly parents as well. Dilorom has requested a loan of 7000 Somoni to restock her clothing inventory. An optimistic businesswoman, Dilorom plans to use the loan to continue developing her business and supporting her family.

loans.use: Purchasing clothing for men

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
This is Evelyn P., 33 years old, from Malibay, Pasay City. Her husband Ruel, 34, is a pedicab driver. One of their two children is now in grade school.

Evelyn sets up a table in an alley near their house and sells rice cakes and other snacks and goodies. She makes good sales every day, primarily because of her business location, although she just started with this business last year. Their pedicab (rickshaw) provides additional income for the family. Evelyn earns more than P13,000 a month.

Last year, she joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative and has since been enjoying the many benefits it provides for its members. Evelyn applied recently for a loan from CCT in the amount of P13,000 for the expansion of her business.

Evelyn works really hard because she wants her children to finish studying. She hopes also to formalize her stall and make it into a full-blown restaurant someday. She also dreams of having a new house and lot.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents Family.

loans.use: business expansion

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda R. is from the village of San Pedro. She is 61 years old. Erlinda is widowed and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Erlinda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She works to help her husband financially to provide for the family.

Mariama is a petty trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. Mariama sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. She has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Jumanazar

texts.en:
H. Jumanazar was born in 1950 and is married with two children. As an aspiring and hard-working man, he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. Thus, when he joined IMON International last year, he was able to make much progress with his previous loan, which he invested mostly in crop farming.

Then, he saw a new business opportunity: rearing calves, which is very profitable because of the constant demand for meat at the market. Given this loan, Jumanazar will purchase calves and feed for them to expand his business. He plans to use the profits from his business to improve the structure of his home and improve the standard of living of his family.

loans.use: Purchasing calves in order to expand his business

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en:
K. Nazakat comes from a humble family but her desire to succeed in life superseded her economic condition. At an early age she learned to make new and different articles of women's national dresses. Thanks to her excellent work, Nazakat won the admiration and loyalty of her clients. With the benefits she obtained she was able to improve the living conditions of her family.

Together with her husband, she has 4 children and the wish of this hard-working mother is to provide the best future for her children. In order to realize her plans for which she works hard, Nazakat appeals to your caring heart and requests a loan to buy the materials necessary to continue making her fine articles of dress. Let’s support this excellent seamstress so she can continue sewing her elegant and distinguished articles of national dress.

loans.use: Purchasing fabrics for sewing women's national dress

loans.name: Boubacar Mahaye

texts.fr:
Né le 24 septembre 1980 à Bougouni (région de Sikasso), Monsieur  Boubacar Mahaye C.  est marié et vit avec son épouse dans une  grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier Babemba, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur C. n’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer dans les études, il s’est très vite initié à un métier, à savoir celui de la  construction métallique, depuis très jeune. Il travaille actuellement avec deux apprentis à son propre compte, il y a environ une année et il est beaucoup sollicité  de la plupart de ses clients pour la qualité de ses prestations.
Actuellement pour mieux répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, il sollicite  un prêt  au niveau de Soro Yiriwaso afin  d’acheter, une machine de soudure, une meule, quelques barres de fer U, Z, des baguettes, etc. Ses  matériels sont achetés sur place et servirons à concevoir des produits (des chaises, tables, bancs, etc.)  destinés à la vente au comptant surtout.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on September 24, 1980 in Bougouni (region of Sikasso), Mr. Boubacar Mahaye C. is married and lives with his wife in a large traditional extended family in Babemba, an outlying district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  Not having had the chance to continue his education, he soon got introduced at a young age to a trade, namely metalwork.  He has been working for about a year with two apprentices in his own business.  And he is in high demand by most of his customers for the quality of his work.  At the moment, in order to respond better to the expectations of his every-growing customer base, he's requesting a loan from Soro Yiriwaso to purchase a welding machine, a grinding wheel, a few U and Z iron bars, welding rods, etc.  His supplies and equipment are bought locally and will be used to design products (chairs, tables, benches, etc.) destined for sale, for cash in particular.  With the loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 95,000 francs CFA that will essentially be used to increase his business capital, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy welding supplies and equipment

loans.name: Ndoliba

texts.en:
Ndoliba is sixty years old. She is widowed and has given birth to two children. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Ndoliba works hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a petty trader. Ndoliba trades in all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Ndoliba has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Makhfirat

texts.en:
K. Makhfirat is a married woman and has 4 children. She has been running her own business for 15 years already. Makhfirat sells clothes for kids in a store which is located in one of the intensively inhabited parts of the local market. She is very nice and polite and has many customers. The business is quite stable and serves as a significant source of income for the family.

Makhfirat has been a client of IMON for more than 4 years. She has managed to pay all her loans accurately and precisely. Now she requests 7000 Somoni to increase the range of her goods. Makhfirat deeply appreciates your support and sincerely thanks all of you.

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for kids for the autumn/winter season

loans.name: Drissa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Drissa B. est un célibataire de 25 ans, qui est sous-couvert de son grand frère vivant à Hamdallaye “Zantiguibougou”, un des quartiers périphériques de ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  B. après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié  il y a plus deux  ans aux activités de commerce, notamment  celle de l’achat et de la vente d’articles divers (tels l’huile alimentaire, le sel,  les pâtes alimentaires : le spaghetti, le savon etc). Il dispose d’une place au marché avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes de ménages. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Afin de  satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux  mois. Il  est à son premier prêt individuel.
 Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, 1 fût d’huile alimentaire, 2 cartons de spaghetti, 1 sac de sel  et quelques cartons de savons. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la place avant de les revendre en détail, au  comptant et à crédit  .
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Drissa B., aged 25, is unmarried and in the care of his older brother living in Hamdallaye “Zantiguibougou”, an outlying district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked at several businesses unsuccessfully, Mr. B. got introduced over two years ago to commerce, especially the buying and selling of various goods (such as cooking oil, salt, pasta, soap, etc.) He has a spot at the marketplace with customers composed essentially of housewives. He is in high demand by his customers for the quality of his merchandise. To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two months ago. He is now on his first individual loan. With this loan, he intends to purchase a barrel of cooking oil, 2 boxes of spaghetti, a sack of salt, and a few boxes of soap. He stocks up with local wholesale merchants and then sells his goods retail, cash or credit accepted. With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit if 80,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase his business capital, to assist with family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods

loans.name: Gulnora

texts.en:
Y. Gulnora is married and has three children. She runs a business selling men’s socks at the market of Tursunzade, Tajikistan. Her business exhibits good economic characteristics and fundamentals.

Gulnora has a unique talent for identifying new opportunities and determining appropriate growth policies for her business. She has been in this trade for 14 years.

Gulnora would like to get a loan of 5000 Somoni ($1150 USD) to increase her working capital so that she can continue working to improve her business. We believe her natural ability to please her customers by perceiving their needs and offering speedy, courteous service will help Gulnora achieve her goals, sustain her success,and win out as an entrepreneur.

loans.use: Increasing working capital with the purpose of development of business

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to three children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Sarah works to help her husband financially to provide for the family. Sarah is a petty trader. She sells all kinds of cereals such as maize, beans, groundnuts, etc. She procures the goods from nearby communities. She sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers.

Sarah has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married with four children, aged between 16 and 24 years. Rehema owns a two-roomed house where she is staying with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. Rehema takes care of additional family members.

Rehema pays for transport costs to and from shopping. She works six days a week. On average she receives at least 30 customers a day .She works on the outskirts of Kampala.

Rehema has been in hr business for ten years and with MCDT for eight years also, and she is servicing her sixteenth loan, working with the same group-mates. Her challenges include defaulters and the increasing price of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Fuseina

texts.en:
Fuseina is thirty years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Fuseina is a petty trader. She sells smoked fish. She procures the smoked fish from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. Fuseina has been in business for some time now and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy smoked fish

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
B. Mavluda is 51 years old. She is married and the loving mother of two children. With the purpose of supporting her family, Mavluda is selling women’s clothing. She has been in this business already for 15 years. Over these years, she gained experience in choosing such goods that are of good quality and meet the requirements of customers with various levels of income. The business is very stable so that it allows Mavluda to improve the living of the family.

Mavluda has been working with IMON for more than a year. She managed her previous loans with accuracy and made all the payments in a timely manner. Today Mavluda requests 5000 Somoni in order to expand her inventory. Mavluda would like to thank everyone supporting her and to ensure that she’ll pay back the loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods to sell

loans.name: Malamine

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Malamine D. a 27 ans, célibataire, il réside dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Hamdallaye Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur D. après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès notamment la vente de carburants, s’est initié au domaine du commerce plus précisément la vente des articles divers d’Alimentation (Eau minérale, boisson,  savon, thé Lipton, et cartes de recharge de téléphone Malitel/Orange, etc.) dans une boutique située à Wayerma I Sikasso. Il mène cette activité il y a environ trois  ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, auprès de commerçants grossistes sur place et des représentants des deux réseaux de télécommunication : 10 paquets de boissons NBB, 30 cartons d’Eaux minérales, 2 cartons de lipton, 5 cartons de savons et de cartes de recharge Malitel/Orange, etc. Il vend ses marchandises en gros et en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des toutes couches sociales de la ville.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Malamine D. is 27 years old and single. He lives in a large traditional extended family in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After running several activities unsuccessfully, in particular, the sale of fuel, Mr. D. learned the field of retail business. More precisely, he now sells various food items (Mineral water, beverages, soap, Lipton tea and mobile phone cards recharge Malite / Orange etc...) in a shop located in Wayerma I Sikasso. He has been in this business for about three years. He is very much in demand by his customers for the quality of his products.

To meet the demand of his ever increasing customers, he decided to join the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, this is his first individual loan with them.

With this loan, he hopes to buy from local wholesale merchants and from representatives of the two telecommunications networks:

10 packs of beverages NBB, 30 boxes of mineral water, 2 boxes of Lipton, 5 boxes of soap, and mobile phone recharge cards Malite / Orange etc...

He sells his items wholesale or retail to customers generally from the town' s various social strata.

With this loan, he plans on making a monthly profit of 250 000 FCFA, which he will use mainly to increase his business, contribute to the family's expenses, pay back his loan and invest the rest in his activity.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various food items.

loans.name: Bobokhon

texts.en:
B. Bobokhon is 49 years old and the father of 4 children. His spouse is a housewife. Bobokhon owns a field for cultivating potatoes, onions, and wheat in order to earn a living. On this plantation, Bobokhon now cannot do any planting because he does not have enough money for cultivating his crops. In order to deal with this problem, he decided to ask for a loan of 1200 USD to buy seeds and fertilizer. Bobokhon counts on this opportunity to obtain a better yield, in order to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: Purchasing seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mariatou

texts.fr:
Née le 27 Octobre 1969 à Sikasso, Mariatou S. est mariée et mère de  5 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sabaribougou, une localité située à environ 6km de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école pour des raisons sociales, cette  femme s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et de vente des fruits et légumes, d’oignons et de tubercules (Pomme de terre, igname) depuis plus de trente  ans. Elle mène son activité à la gare routière de Sikasso, en face de compagnie de transport “SAMA TRNSPORT”, un endroit très fréquenté. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de quatre  ans. Après un prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel . 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt,  9 sacs d’oignons et 10 sacs de pomme de terre à Bamako en provenance de Dakar afin de les revendre en détail et au comptant à une clientèle composée généralement de  voyageurs et surtout étrangers.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mariatou S., a married mother of 5, was born on October 27, 1969 in Sikasso. She lives with her husband and their children in Sabaribougou, a town located roughly 6km outside the city of Sikasso (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
Not having had the chance to go to school for social reasons, she started buying and selling fruits and vegetables – onions and tubers (potatoes, yams) – over thirty years ago. She sets up shop at the Sikasso bus station, a popular location across from the transport company “SAMA TRNSPORT.”
Hoping to better satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso over 4 years ago. After a solidarity loan (a group loan) with a group of local women, she is on her 4th individual loan. With this loan, she plans to go to Bamako to buy 9 bags of onions and 10 sacks of potatoes grown in Dakar, to then resell to mainly travellers and foreigners.
With this loan, she anticipates monthly profits of 70,000 XOF, which will mainly be used to increase her working capital, contribute to family expenses and pay interest on her loan. She will invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy onions and potatoes

loans.name: Yodgor

texts.en:
Yodgor G. is 26 years old. He is married and has one child. A young entrepreneur, Yodgor sells different kinds of detergents like soap, shampoo, tooth paste, shaving cream, washing powder and others in his store. Yodgor is not alone in this business as his wife actively helps him with sales. Yodgor requests a loan of $1000 to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once and a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. Yodgor's main goal is to educate his beloved child so that someday he'll become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase detergents and increase the range of goods to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is 26 years old. She is married and has given birth to one boy who is in school. She lives with her son and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Ama works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a trader. She trades in foodstuffs such as cassava flour. She procures the goods from nearby communities and sells at the local market to food vendors and retailers. Ama also treks to get supplies.

She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her child the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs.

loans.name: The Young Generation Group

texts.en:
This is Mamusu B., Ramatu B., and Zainab T.. They call their group Tataisumpa. 

Mamusu B. (right) is the leader of this group. Mamusu is a 36 year-old widow with 2 children. Mamusu owns a small store selling general household goods such as pots and pans, bug sprays, and cosmetics. She has been in business for 4 years.

This is the first loan these entrepreneurs have requested from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods into their businesses so that sales and profit will increase. Consequently their standard of living will also improve. They will be in a better position to look after themselves and their children in terms of feeding, clothing, sending them to school and providing them with medical care in case they fall sick.

loans.use: Expansion of business.

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace A. is 44 years old. She is married with 6 children between 14 and 23 years old. All her children go to to school. She owns a six-room house where she resides with eight people. (She also takes care of additional family members.) The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. 

Peace works 7 days a week selling fried and raw cassava. She works in the outskirts of Kampala. Peace has been in this business for 7 months and in MCDT for 5 years servicing her tenth loan. She will use this loan to buy more sacks of cassava and cooking oil for frying cassava. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start going to farmers directly.

loans.use: To buy more cassava and cooking oil.

loans.name: Lantana

texts.en:
Lantana is 45 years old. She is married and has given birth to two children, both in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana.

Lantana works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. Lantana cooks and sells rice with stew. She sells by the road side from morning till evening. She procures the goods from nearby towns. 

Lantana has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk. She hopes to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice.

loans.name: Lassina

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lassina O.  est âgé de plus de 35 ans, marié et père de trois  enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Wayerma II, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur O. après avoir mener plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine du commerce et aujourd’hui, il dispose d’une boutique devant le domicile conjugal où il mène cette activité d’achat et de vente des articles divers (Cigarettes, bonbons, allumettes, Chewing-gum, laits en poudre, Thés, sucre, savons, etc) depuis plus de trois ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Après le remboursement du précédent prêt avec succès, il sollicite ainsi un deuxième prêt individuel afin de mieux répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle.
 Avec ce deuxième prêt, il compte acheter, 5 cartons du thé, 3 sacs du sucre, 2 sacs de bonbons différents, 30 paquets de Chemine-gum 30 paquets d’allumettes, 10 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes, 5 cartons de savons, 4 paquets de boissons NBB, 4 casiers de boissons BRAMALI, etc. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de place avant de les revendre en détail  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de voisins.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce,  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Lassina O. is over 35 years of age, married and the father of three children. He lives with his family in Wayerma ll, the principal city of Sikasso ( third administrative region of the Republic of Mali ) After attempted several unsuccessful businesses, Mr. Outtara started selling a variety of products from a kiosk located in front of an apartment living complex selling cigarettes, candies, matches, chewing gum, powered milk, teas, sugar, soaps etc. He is highly sought after by his clients for the quality of his products. To satisfy the needs of his increasing number of clients, he decided last year to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance group. After successfully paying off his first loan, he now requests a second individual loan to better meet his customers needs. With this second loan he plans to buy, 5 boxes of tea, 3 sacks of sugar, 2 sacks of assorted candies, 30 packages of chewing gum, 30 packages of matches, 10 assorted cartons of cigarettes, 5 cartons of soap, 4 boxes of NBB drinks, 4 crates of Bramali drinks, etc. He buys his supplies from local wholesalers then resells them at retail prices for cash or credit, to his neighborhood clients. He expects to earn a profit of 150,000 FCFA which will be used to increase his business operating capital, contribute to the family expenses, meet his loan payments and invest into his business.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of products for resale

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S. est une femme de 46 ans elle est mariée et mère de 9 enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de YAMATOGNE depuis 1 an et demi. Avec son crédit elle développe une petite activité de vente de fournitures scolaires qui lui permet de dégager des bénéfices pour la prise en charge quotidienne de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou S. is a 45-year old woman and she is married and is the mother of 9 children. She has been a member of the Yamatogne village bank for the past year and a half. She will invest her loan in a small business selling school supplies, which provides her an income to provide for the daily needs of her family.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital.

loans.name: Qala-E-Ahamd Khan Group

texts.en:
Ziaudin is the group leader of the Qala-e-Ahamd K. group. This group has four male members. They live in district 16th of Kabul Afghanistan.
Ziaudin is married with 5 children. He has a shop where he sells different kinds of cosmetics. He wants use the loan to buy more new and good quality cosmetics. 
Purdel has a fruit cart where he works hard to support his family of 6 members. 
Roki has the shop that sells video cassette. He wants to expand his business to attract more clients to his shop.  Masiullah, the last member of the group, is a side road seller. With the loan he wants to grow his business and have a new small shop, if possible.
They all have requested a group loan of 40000 Afghani.
Each of the group members says that Kiva is an effective process.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
Maribeth G. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 34 years old and married. To make a living, Maribeth owns and operates a general store. Her main source of income comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Maribeth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month. In 2006, Maribeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribeth successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP that she used to purchase additional products to sell. Maribeth is requesting her 8th loan for 14900 PHP that she will use to purchase additional inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Kobiljon

texts.en: I. Kobiljon is 27 years old. He is married with three children. Nine years ago, he started his business selling cell phones. Kobiljon believes that this business is profitable and the generated income allows him to support his family. However, he thinks that it is expensive to purchase the cell phones locally and it will save money to purchase the goods in China. Kobiljon requests $800 for this purpose. This is his first loan and Kobiljon is grateful to all supporting him and promises to repay the loan promptly. loans.use: Purchasing cell phones from China to sell

loans.name: Fotima

texts.en: M. Fotima’s passion lies in her children. A married mother of three, Fotima started her business selling the national Tajik footwear called “galosh” with the goal of providing a better standard of living for her family. For the past seven years, Fotima has successfully operated her business at the market. With her profits, she not only has improved the living standards for her children but she has been able to support her elderly parents as well. Fotima has requested a loan of $1,000 to restock her inventory. An optimistic businesswoman, Fotima plans to use the loan to continue developing her business and supporting her family. loans.use: To restock her inventory

loans.name: Sherifa

texts.en:
Sherifa is 24 years old. She is married and has given birth to one girl, who is in school. She lives with her daughter and husband in a rented apartment in a busy commercial town called Ejura in the Ashanti region of Ghana. 

Sherifa works to support her husband financially to provide for the family. She is a trader. She sells provisions. She hawks to sell her provisions. Sherifa procures the goods from nearby towns. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is hopeful to give her child the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Abdurahmon

texts.en:
P. Abdurahmon is 56 years old. He is married with four children. Abdurahmon's goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life to get ahead and to fulfill his goals. He is a taxi driver and travels through the streets of Istaravshan, Tajikistan in search of customers. He has owned his business for five years. Currently, Abdurahmon’s car needs some repair and he wants to borrow $1000 USD. The financing will go toward repairing his vehicle. Abdurahmon thanks Kiva and all lenders that make this help possible.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to repair his car

loans.name: Albert

texts.en: Albert is 27 years old. He is married and has two children. Both of his children attend elementary school. He operates a soft drink shop and sells items like Coke, canned drinks etc. He is also into selling food items such as beans, maize and groundnuts. He has been in this business for ten years now. Through the business, he has managed to buy a plot of land where he wants to build his house rather than renting. He buys his goods from the farming communities in the northern region of Ghana. He wants a loan to increase his working capital so that his dream of buying goods in bulk can be achieved. In this way, he can supply a large number of customers and increase his market size and his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy products in bulk

loans.name: Aniouvi Eugénie

texts.fr: A. Aniouvi Eugénie est née le 02 Septembre 1956 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Aniouvi Eugénie vit depuis trente ans au quartier Agbokou à Porto-Novo. Mariée à CHANVOEDOU Nathaniel un éleveur,  Aniouvi Eugénie est mère de quatre enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Aniouvi Eugénie a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire et vend depuis une quinzaine d’année, divers biscuits, bombons, ainsi que des fruits devant l’Eglise catholique Sainte Anne de Porto-Novo. Aniouvi Eugénie vend également du charbon de bois et de la boisson alcoolisée locale « sodabi ». Aniouvi Eugénie s’approvisionne au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Aniouvi Eugénie sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Aniouvi Eugenie A. was born on September 2, 1956 in Porto-Novo, the capital city of Benin. Aniouvi Eugenie has lived in the Agbokou district in Porto-Novo for the past 30 years. She is married to farmer named Nathaniel Chanvoedou. Aniouvi Eugenie is the mother of four children, some of whom are going to school. As a couple they both support their family. Aniouvi Eugenie stopped dropped out of high school and she has been in sales for the past 15 years, selling cookies, candy, and fruit in fron of the Catholic church Sainte Anne de Porto-Novo. Aniouvi Eugenie also sells wood coal and a popular alcoholic drink named "sodabi". Aniouvi Eugenie buys her products at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She is a long-term client of Alide (Kiva Field Partner) having already benefitted from two past loans, both of which were repaid. In order to increase her working capital and to better meet the needs of her clients, Aniouvi Eugenie is requesting a third loan through Alide.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cookies and sacks of wood coal.

loans.name: Siyama

texts.en:
Siyama M. is currently in the business of selling maize and shorgum at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase peeled and dried cassava to sell.  Siyama is 32 years old and is married to a security guard. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for stocking more cereals to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education,human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase peeled and dried cassava to sell

loans.name: Ikhtiyor

texts.en:
R. Ikhtiyor is a family man who wishes to increase his business to be able to better support his family and offer them a better quality of life. Eight years ago, Ikhtiyor started by selling blankets and counterpanes (bedspreads). His business has grown little by little and now offers greater variety and fashions. Today, Ikhtiyor has been working with Kiva partner IMON International for more than three years and feels very satisfied with the support offered to him because it has allowed him to increase his business, satisfy the needs of his customers and support his family. Ikhtiyor is asking to borrow $1,500 USD in order to purchase new goods. He wants to develop his business and increase his income to save money and create a better life for his family.

loans.use: To purchase new retail goods.

loans.name: Abdunabi

texts.en:
R. Abdunabi is 28 years-old and a married father of two children. Abdunabi owns a shop in which he sells blankets and counterpane (bedspreads), a business he has been running for the last six years. The income he earns allows him to feed his family. To meet his customers constantly growing demands, Abdunabi would like to increase his shop’s capacity. The profits from these sales will allow him to improve his living conditions. The loan will greatly improve Abdunabi’s income and his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods.

loans.name: Orif

texts.en:
R. Orif is 47 years-old and married with three children. For the last 15 years, Orif has been providing transport services. As a rule he is working in his region only. At the same time, together with the help of his wife and children, he raises cattle at his house which gives additional income to his family. Currently Orif’s truck needs repairs and he is asking for a loan of $1,500 US. Orif promises to pay the loan on time and thanks everyone for their support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. loans.use: Truck repair.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa B. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 33 years-old and married with three school-aged children. Teresa owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables and root crops for sale. Teresa has been engaged in her business for over four years with an approximate average monthly earning of 2,000 PHP.

In 2007, Teresa joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase construction materials needed for house improvement. Teresa is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Teresa from PMPC. She plans to make a better shelter for the family to live. (The man together with Teresa in the picture is her husband.)

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Elida

texts.en:
Elida W. is currently in the business of selling at the saloon and is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials to sell. Elida is 30 years-old and is married with a husband that is a driver. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits generated from her loan, she hopes to be able to start an internet café.

loans.name: Rali

texts.fr: S. Rali est née le 11 Août 1958 au Cameroun en Afrique. Rali vit depuis son jeune âge au quartier Agbokou à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Rali est une veuve et mère de deux enfants tous scolarisés, dont un est à sa charge. Rali vit seule avec ses enfants, et les charges de la famille sont supportées par elle seule. Rali n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour subvenir aux besoins quotidiens de ses enfants, Rali vend depuis une dizaine d’année, des colas (produits locaux), des mèches de réchaud, des bouteilles et de « Adindon », servant à faire de sauce locale au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Rali s’approvisionne à Adjarra, village situé non loin de Porto-Novo. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Rali sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé pour augmenter la taille de son activité et de sa clientèle afin de mieux satisfaire les besoins de ses enfants.
texts.en:
S. Rali was born on August 11, 1958 in Cameroun in Africa. Rali has been living since childhood in the Agbokou district in Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Bénin. Rali is a widow and the mother of two children, one of whom is still under her care. Rali lives alone with her children and she is the only breadwinner for the little family.

Rali never went to school. To support her children, Rali has been selling kolas (local products), stove wicks, bottles and 'adindon', used locally to make stews, for some 10 years in the market of Ouando in Porto-Novo. Rali does her buying in Adjarra, a village situated not far from Porto-Novo.

She has been a client of ALIDé for a long time and has already received two loans that she has repaid correctly. Rali is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to grow her little business and her clientele so that she can better cater for the needs of her children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of kola nuts, stove wicks, and local condiments

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa is a 40 year-old woman. She is married and has two children who are attending school. She lives with her husband in her matrimonial home. She is an achiever and a resourceful mother. She loves selling goods, the business through which she makes a living. For the last nine years, Yaa has traded in food such as plantains and cassava. She treks to surrounding villages in the community to purchase bulk stock of plantains from the farmers and sells to her customers.  Due to inadequate working capital, she is not able to purchase enough stock to make sufficient profit to support her family.  With the loan, she wants to purchase a bulk supply of plantains and cassava to enable her to increase her business.

loans.use: To purchase bulk cassava and plantains.

loans.name: Khushbakht

texts.en:
U. Khushbakht is 22 years-old and married with one child. Khushbakht shoots videos of weddings and other family occasions. He has been in this business for about four years. Khushbakht tries to be creative in his job and when shooting the event and preparing the tape, he works as if he is making films. In the neighborhood, Khushbakht is known as a very hard-working and diligent operator so he has many clients that make the business successful and bring a stable income to his family. Today Khushbakht is asking for a loan of $ 600 US to purchase a computer for his business. This is the fifth loan of Khushbakht from Kiva partner IMON and he would like to assure everyone supporting him that he will repay the loan on time. He expresses his gratitude to everyone.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve agricultural production and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still lives in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a computer.

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is a 35 year-old widow who lives alone. She sells food items such as beans, maize and groundnut. She has been in this business for four years and makes her living from the business profits. She buys her goods from Techiman in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana and sells at the market square. She would like a loan to increase her working capital so that her dream of buying goods in bulk can be achieved. In this way, she can supply a larger number of customers increasing her market size and therefore her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk.

texts.en:

Khamis is 32 years-old and married with a husband that is a soldier. She has seven children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa started her fish business twenty years ago at a community market where she lives. She prepares and serves her customers very tasty fish and for that reason she has many fans.  She buys fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana.  Yaa is 50 years-old, married and the mother of seven children. Two of her children are in school while the rest live independently. She supports her children from the business proceeds. She depends on that for their food, school bills and sometimes their medical bills. She is asking for a loan in order to increase her stock of assorted fish and therefore to increase her income so that she can support her children's education and the business growth. She hopes to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more fish.

loans.name: Wenifreda

texts.en:
Wenifreda J. is from the village of Sulangon. She is 46 years old. Wenifreda is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Wenifreda owns & operates a business providing motorcycle transport service to local community members. Wenifreda has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Wenifreda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wenifreda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Wenifreda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Wenifreda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

She has one child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to develop it into a hotel.

texts.en: Afia is 30 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives with her husband and the children. Currently all her children are schooling in the community. She is a local manufacturer of soap. She combines materials like palm oil, soda powder, cocoa pods and coconut oil to make her soaps. She is not able to produce in large quantities due to lack of funds. She wants to take advantage of the loan facility to buy more raw materials and processing equipment to scale up production. She hopes to increase her income to support her children's education.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide her children with necessities like clothes, school bags, shoes, etc.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is a 48-year-old trader. She is married and has one child, who is currently in school. She trades in lace materials, textiles and clothing materials. Lace material is very useful in room and office decorations.  For lack of adequate working capital, Grace buys only a few stocks of lace materials at a time, and sells them through hawking. She believes the loan will enable her to grow her business to the desired level. With the loan, she wants to purchase lace materials and textiles in bulk. She hopes to use part of her profit to provide her child with a quality education.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of lace materials and textile

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has been operating his retail shop in Naivasha for the last 10 years.  He is 64 years old, married to Ann Wairimu and has 2 children who are still in high school.

John was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his second loan.  He paid off his first loan in full, which he used to expand his business premises. With this loan, John will purchase more cereal to sell in his shop.

In the future, John wants to expand his business and supply cereal at both the retail and wholesale level.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. She has a lot of experience in this business which she has been engaged in since her childhood. She takes delivery of stock from the farming communities in the northern part of Ghana. She is requesting a loan to expand the amount of stock she has to offer. An improved income will help her support her household, especially in helping with the children's eduction.

loans.name: Sahalatu

texts.en: Sahalatu is 35 years old and is a mother of four children. Three are in school and her youngest is still breastfeeding. To support her household, she has been selling cereals like beans, maize, millet, rice and groundnuts in the community market to her loyal customers. She says selling these products is very lucrative. She has been in business for the last five years now and has gained lots of business experience. She takes delivery of stock from the farming communities in the northern part of Ghana and from some in Burkina Faso. She is requesting the loan to increase her stock as we approach the Christmas festivities. She believes this would enable her make a good income to support her family, especially for their education. She would be grateful for your assistance.

He paid off the first loan already, which he used to buy sheep, which he rears and then resells. With this loan, Sammy plans to buy more sheep, which he will rear and sell after they have grown up. He has dreams of having a large number of both sheep and cattle which he will use to supply both the Naivasha market and other markets (especially big towns around Naivasha).

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is 40 years old, married, and the mother of five children. Three are currently in school and two are working. 

To provide for the famly Mariama has been in food production for 8 years. She is a food vendor and serves food like waakye. To make waakye local rice grain is mixed with beans. Many Ghanaians enjoy it as it has local taste. 

Mariama says demand for food is higher but she does not have adequate funds to expand. She will use the loan to buy meat and rice to increase her efficiency at producing larger quantities. 

She believes this will help expand her business and raise more income, allowing her to support her children’s educational needs. She would be grateful for the assistance

loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, vegetables, beans, meat, firewood.

loans.name: Hellen Wambui

texts.en:
Hellen Wambui N. is married and resides in Nairobi. Hellen believes she is hardworking. She has been in the housing rental business for 17 years The people residing in her rental houses are mainly casual laborers and business people of the area.

Hellen was introduced to KADET through existing clients. She intends to use this loan to renovate her rental houses (painting and repairing walls).

With the extra profits she intends to purchase more real estate.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their families across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To renovate her rental homes (paint and repair walls)

loans.name: Igembe Group

texts.en:
Edith R., age 43, is a widow with four children whose ages are 23, 22, 17 and 12. She sells chickens and chicks in a business that she started two years ago. Edith works daily from 6 a.m. until 6 p.m. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $150.

This will be Edith’s first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use the loan to buy chicken feed and chicks to raise and then sell. She hopes to use any extra profit to care for herself and her family, and improve their lives.
	
Edith will share this loan with her loan sub-group, which is a part of the larger group "Igembe," which means "hoe" in Kiswahili. Within this sub-group, Lulu has a shop, Lukresia is a food vendor, Justa raises and sells chickens and Veronika has a grocery. The members of the group hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.  

In the picture, Edith is in the center wearing glasses.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and chicken feed

loans.name: Javan

texts.en:
Javan has been repairing motorcycles in Njabini, on the outskirts of Naivasha town, for the last 13 years.  He is 34 years old, married to Julia Wairimu and has three school-going children.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend and this will be his sixth loan. He plans to use the money to buy spare parts as stock for his motorcycle-repair business. He has a good credit history.

He plans to grow his business and also stock motorbikes to sell in the future.  

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy more spare parts for his motorcyle-repair business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia J. is currently in the business of growing and selling yams and carrots. She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal to sell. Lucia is 30 years old and married to a policeman. She has six children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis has operated his small restaurant in Njabini, in the outskirts of Naivasha town, for the last fifteen years. He is 49 years old, married to Mary Wanja, and has four school-going children. Francis was introduced to KADET by his friend, and this will be his 4th loan. With this loan, Francis plans to buy dry foodstuffs in bulk (which is cheaper) for his business. Francis plans to move into a bigger premises in the near future and open a bigger restaurant that will cater to many people. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy dry foodstuffs in bulk to sell in his restaurant

loans.name: Aisheitu

texts.en:
Aisheitu is 27 years old and a mother with three children. Two of her kids are in school.

To support her household, Aisheitu sells cereals like local rice to her loyal customers in the community market. She says the selling of this product is very lucrative and she has been in business for two years now.

Aisheitu takes delivery of stock from the farming communities. Therefore, she wants the loan to expand her inventory to enable her to make a good income to support her family, especially their education. She hopes to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cereals like rice

loans.name: Barikisu

texts.en:
Barikisu is a 47-year-old woman. She is married and is the mother of six children of whom one is currently in school.

Barikisu is a food vendor and sells kenkey. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains and is taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many Ghanaians as breakfast, lunch and supper.

Barikisu wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She saves part of her profits as an investment for the future. She would be very grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for making kenkey

loans.name: Barika

texts.en: Barika is 29 years old. She is a wife and a mother of two kids. Currently, her children are in school. She enjoys selling goods in her business to make a living. She has been selling tubers of yam for five years now to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of yam from the farmers. This saves her from intermediaries who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. She wants to use the loan to buy yam in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school.

loans.use: To buy bulk of yam

loans.name: Malamanu

texts.en: Malamuna is a 50-year-old local restaurant operator, who is married and has seven children. She started her operations seven years ago. She prepares and sells local foods like omotuo (rice balls), banku and other local dishes. Omotuo is prepared from rice, taken with all kinds of soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. With her tasty meals she has attracted lots of customers in the area where she serves, therefore it has become necessary to employ additional hands to assist her in food delivery service. She says prices of raw materials have gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditure.
