Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
EL señor Francisco S. es padre de familia y tiene tres hijos menores de edad que les quiere dar lo mejor. 
Tiene poco tiempo que adquirió su vivienda por medio del crédito gubernamental, pero le esta haciendo falta algunos detalles, pero para el lo mas la barda alrededor de la casa ya que es una seguridad para su familia. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que realizara la mejora. Planea pagar el crédito con los ingresos que obtiene de su empleo en una fábrica en el departamento de fabricación.Ya ha tenido un crédito con FVP el cual pago puntual mente.
texts.en:
Sr. Francisco S. is the father of three dependent children for whom he desires to provide the best.

His home is lacking a few details, but the most important element that is missing is a security wall around his house in order to provide protection for his family. Francisco does not have the time to apply for assistance from the government.

For this reason, he is requesting a loan to pay for the materials and labor for someone to make this improvement. He plans to repay the loan from his earnings as an employee at a manufacturing plant. Francisco has one previous loan with FVP that was repaid on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a security wall

loans.name: Diosa

texts.en:
Diosa B. is from the village of Matagana, Claveria Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Diosa is married and has 2 school-aged children. Diosa sells personal products such as lotions, cologne, dresses, and other items in the local community. Diosa has been engaged in her business for more than 7 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Diosa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Diosa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more varied inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Make the down payment on a house to qualify for a government loan

loans.name: Crisryan

texts.en:
Crisryan B. is from the village of Saray, Salay Misamis Oriental. He is 29 years old. Crisryan is married and has 4 young children. Crisryan is starting a business venture selling firewood in the local community. 

In 2009, Crisryan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Crisryan is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP to start his firewood business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase firewood for resale

loans.name: Roman

texts.es: El señor Román vive con su esposa la señora María Luisa Téllez y juntos forman una familia integrada por 2 hijos en edad escolar. El labora para una empresa en el área de vigilancia desde hace un año y su esposa por su parte trabaja en una residencia realizando labores domesticas desde hace 2 años. Juntos como una familia unida iniciaron un negocio  de venta de hamburguesas y burritos de nombre “El cuadro“los fines de semana para poder atenderlo eficientemente. Por una situación de enfermedad de uno de sus hijos tuvieron que cerrar el negocio y por tal motivo solicitan este crédito ahora que su situación ha mejorado desean invertir nuevamente en su negocio ya que la clientela los sigue buscando.
texts.en:
Román lives with his wife María Luisa Téllez. They form a family together with their two school-aged children. Román has worked for a security company for a year, and his wife has worked as a housekeeper in a private residence for two years. As a close family they started up a business together, selling hamburgers and burritos under the name “El cuadro“ (The block) during weekends when they had the opportunity to tend to their stall efficiently. When one of their children fell ill they had to close the business, but now that they have recuperated Román and María Luisa are applying for a loan so that they can set up their business again since their customers continue to ask after them.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the purchase of products to make and sell food

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.en:
Clemencia D. owns and operates a specialized retail store selling shampoo, soap and candies in her community. She is 43 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Tagulalo, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Clemencia has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos a month.

In 2007, Clemencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to improve and expand her business. Clemencia is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ramona

texts.es: La señora Ramona es casada con el señor Alberto Aguiñaga y ambos viven solitos y establecieron un negocio propio desde hace 1 año. Ellos están tramitando este crédito para la inversión en su negocio y mediante esta inversión su negocio crecerá y su clientela estará satisfecha
texts.en:
Ramona is married to Alberto Aguiñaga. They live all by themselves and they established their own business one year ago. They are applying for a loan to invest in their business so that it will grow and their customers will be satisfied.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: La señora Silvia S. J. lleva 18 años casada con su esposo llamado J Cleofas el cual es el que aporta el ingresos al hogar el trabaja de soldador y la señora es ama de casa, ellos son un matrimonio que a sabido salir adelante con sus esfuerzos, ellos adquirieron una vivienda pero esta deteriorada y le falta hacerle algunas mejoras como lo son el techo, baño y piso, quieren mejorar para poder tener un patrimonio para sus hijos y sobre todo en buenas condiciones para que no pierda valor la vivienda.
texts.en:
Silvia S. J. has been married to her husband J Cleofas for 18 years. He has contributed income to the home from his job as a soldier, while Silvia has worked as a housewife. They have a marriage that has been able to move forward through their efforts. They have purchased a house but it is in bad shape; the roof, bathroom and floors need improving. They want to improve the house to create an asset for their children, which above all should be in good condition so that it does not lose its value.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Roof, bathroom and floor repairs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase natural products

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria D. owns a business venture buying and selling alimango (crabs) retail. She is 56 years old, married and has two adult children. She is from the village of Anonang, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. Victoria has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month.

In 2009, Victoria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase additional crabs to sell. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional crabs to sell

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia C. is from the village of Bolisong, Kinoguitan, Misamis Oriental. She is 50 years old. Alicia is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Alicia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Alicia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Alicia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alicia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Alicia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Alicia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ledenisa

texts.en:
Ledenisa C. is from the village of Anonang, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 33 years old. Ledenisa is married and has two school-aged children. Ledenisa sells "alimango" (crabs) on a retail basis. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling crabs in the local community. Ledenisa has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ledenisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ledenisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional crabs to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Ledenisa from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay tuition for her children. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional crabs to sell

loans.name: María Ana

texts.es:
La señora María Ana G. tiene ya más de diez años dedicándose a la venta de cobertores y sobrecamas, este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia. 
Le está haciendo falta más variedad de mercancía ya que en está temporada de invierno se vende más, tiene ya varios pedidos para entregar pero necesita pagarle al proveedor para que le entregue más mercancía y así poder entregar los pedidos a tiempo. 
Planea pagar el crédito con las ganancias del negocio ya que los gastos familiares los cubrirá su esposo el señor Juan Zenon Hernández, con su empleo como vigilante de una compañía.
texts.en:
Sra. María Ana G. has been selling quilts and bedspreads for more than 10 years. This business serves as a source of income for her family.

María generates more sales during the winter season, but she is currently lacking a wide variety of merchandise. She has several orders to fulfill, but she needs to pay her supplier for the goods she requested. Otherwise, she will not be able to deliver her orders on time. She plans to repay the loan with the proceeds from her business. Her family expenses are covered by her husband, Sr. Juan Zenon Hernández, who works as a company security guard.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase quilts & bedspreads

loans.name: Etrelita

texts.en:
Etrelita C. is from the village of Sugbongcogon, Misamis Oriental. She is 28 years old. Etrelita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Etrelita operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling "Ready to Wear" clothing items in the local community. Etrelita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities.

In 2009, Etrelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Etrelita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Etrelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Martha Josefa

texts.es: La Sra. Martha atiende un kiosco en la Academia de Policias, en la exclusiva zona de seguencoma, donde vende comida, refrescos y otros productos a los cadetes; actividad con la cual mantiene a su hogar, esta separada del esposo, hace estudiar a sus tres hijos, que estan en edad escolar. Sus hijos la ayudan en la atencion en el tiempo que tienen libre. Podemos acotar que la cliente amplio su kiosco y surtio con mucho mas productos gracias a los financiamientos que le dimos.
texts.en:
Martha runs a small shop at the police academy, where she sells food, drinks and other products to the police cadets. This small business helps her maintain her home and pay for the education of her three children, as she is separated from her husband. Her children help her with the business during their free time. We can help her expand her business and stock many more products with the financial support we provide.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her small kiosk and help her grow her business

loans.name: Laurencia

texts.en:
Laurencia M. is from Poblacion Aurora, a village in the province of Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 54 years old. Laurencia is married and has three adult children.

To make a living, Laurencia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling Alimango (mud crabs). While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling crab products in the local community. Laurencia has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities.

In 2009, Laurencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laurencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Laurencia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Laurencia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix G. is from the village of Tagulalo, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. He is 57 years old. Felix is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Felix sells fish that he raises in a fishpond.  Felix has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Felix joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felix has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Felix is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional equipment and feed. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Felix from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

loans.name: Fatys

texts.es:
La Sra.Fatys, alquila un ambiente para la venta de almuerzo familiar, entre los platos que ofrece a diario son: Sopa de maní, Picante de Pollo, bife y los fines de semana platos especiales como el Pescado frito, pescado al Horno, Majadito de pato (plato tipico de Santa Cruz) y otros. También cuenta con la venta de gaseosas, asi como la preparación de refrescos para la venta como el de Mocochinchi (durazno seco)y la Limonada. Cuenta con el apoyo de sus dos hijos para la atención de la pensión. La mayor competencia  que tiene son los dos días de feria (martes y sábados) que se realiza a dos cuadras de la pensión. 
La señora emprendió este negocio hace dos años atrás cuando la situación económica de su familia se ponía difícil, había tomado la decisión de viajar a otro país para mejorar su situación económica, como lo hicieron muchos, pero significaría la desintegración de su  familia y decidió quedarse y trabajar atendiendo una pensión, contando con el apoyo de su familia y la de su hermana quien le ofreció la tienda, actualmente ahora ella alquila la tienda porque ya cuenta con ingresos para cubrir el alquiler como las necesidades de su familia.
El sueño que tiene la señora al margen de mejorar su negocio ofertar nuevos platos ya que la tienda se encuentra en una muy buena ubicación
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatys rents a stall and sells home-styled lunches, amongst the dishes that she serves daily include: peanut soup, spicy chicken, and steak. In the weekends she serves special plates like fried fish, baked fish, duck majadito (a mixture of beef jerky and rice served with a fried egg and a banana—typical dish of Santa Cruz), and others. She also sells sodas and prepares drinks like (dried peaches) and lemonade. She has the help of her two children to take care of her lodgings. Most of the competition that she has is in the two days of the street market (Tuesdays and Saturdays) that are two blocks from her pension.

Mrs. Fatys began this business two years ago when her family’s economic situation was getting complicated. She wanted to travel to another country to better her economic wellbeing like many others have done, but that would separate the family and decided to stay and work. She takes care of a pension with the help of her family and of her sister who offered her the store that she now rents because she has the income to take care of the rent as well as the necessities of her family.

Mrs. Fatys’ dream is to improve her business by providing new dishes since the store is very well located.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in fixed assets.

loans.name: Crusanita

To make a living, Crusanita sells seafood products like fish and shrimp in the local community. Crusanita has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Crusanita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Crusanita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.
